I knew that I would be under-dressed, in a different sense of the word.Very friendly bartenders, no judgment in their eyes at all about my looking like "a suit." One Jack on the rocks, water back, and I was feeling alright. The space is old school fantastic--no pretense, no interior designer, just the feel of Chicago talent seeping out of the walls, floor, ceiling, and current inhabitants.But the place wasn't empty. There was an event going on in the smaller-than-I expected performance room in the back. It turned out that there, in my presence, were hysterical writers, comedians, readers, individuals performing in "Funny Ha Ha," which apparently was a show ten years ago, now back by popular demand, seemingly both by the artists and by the public. Turns out that it was a benefit, and the person at the door must not have been there when I walked in. The charity, I hadn't heard of before: "Tail Waggin' Tutors," which gives students with reading difficulties a chance to read outloud to dogs. I would have thought this was just part of the act, but the emcee said this this was for real. It turns out that the dogs provide a friendly, never-judgmental atmosphere for the kids to practice. What a great idea.  (Don't try this with your average, judgmental cat, ladies and gentlemen, lest it hiss or passive-aggressively walk away!) I gladly went back to the door and chipped in my $10.No wonder the place was packed at 6:30 in the evening. What conviviality, Positive energy. Wonderful senses of intelligent humor. No dumbing down to the lowest common denominator of the masses. And there were masses--shoulder to shoulder SRO in the room. The only think that was dumb was my dumb luck for happening into the place at the perfect time. My only regret was having to leave early and then ending up waiting at the restaurant until after this show would have been over.

3.description: Stopped by this small bar as it is usually a host to all kinds of street fests and musical acts. This time they were hosting the Renegade festivalrenegadecraft.com/chicag…This bar is cash only and don't come in to only use the washroom. Low ceilings and few lights during the day time gives this place a cool relaxed feeling. They do have an ATM inside if you didn't bring cash.

35.description: The husband and I decided that as part of our new year's resolutions we were going to go to some of the divey, live music venues that we've been by a million times and stop in to see random music on random nights... first stop was the Hideout.We got some dinner and drinks at Ada Street and found the house with the Chrismas lights and walked over.  I had a feeling it was going to be judgey hipster central but the door guy and girl bartender were both super nice and welcoming.  It was like being invited into your grandma's basement for a drink.  I loved every part of it.  All of the musicians who walked in seemed to know everyone and it seemed like a comfortable, homey vibe. The music room is great, wide with small tables on the outside and a huge open floor.  The sound was perfect, even sitting up close to the stage everything was crystal clear.  Very cool place and three really unique bands, will definitely be back.

19.description: I'd hesitate to come back here. The beer was cheap and the place is cool, but the sound was so loud that it was distorted. I could hear the band playing loudly in the outer bar, and it sounded better there...but there's not much of a sightline. The bass was super loud--in your chest loud--like heart attack loud. We went to see Robbie Fulks, and after 4 songs, could not take the sound, and left. Also, they allowed so many people into their back room that we literally could barely come and go from our seats in the front row. It had to be way over capacity and that was kind of creepy, knowing that you were stuck wherever you sat, because you could not come and go, without crawling over the others. There was no bar service to your seats because it was so crowded. I appreciate Robbie Fulks, but I doubt I'd go back there to see him. For me, to stand in line 30 minutes, buy a beer, pay $10 a person for the show, and leave 15 after show starts....not much value there. I'll see him at Fitzgeralds when he's there. The Hideout could be a good place....just not when it's that crowded.

28.description: I loved the hideout! Was there over the weekend for a friends birthday and had a blast! Best kept secret in this city. However, the staff SUCKED. The two girls behind the bar were pretty rude from the beginning and then I was over charged for my drinks. $18.50 for a g&t and a High Life? I don't think so. Also witnessed a really drunk guy get charged $10 for a draft beer. I mean, c'mon.Go, have fun, dance your butt off but watch your money.

45.description: Been here a couple times, but most recently for Bingo. As cheesy as it sounds, it was really fun and they gave out cool prizes like organic veggies, baked goods, hideout patches, and t-shirts. They also gave away free hot dogs provided by Hot Doug's which was obviously a major perk. The 2 guys running the show were very entertaining/friendly, but one of them was so clearly inebriated towards the end of the game it got a little annoying. I'm all for weirdness but he was screaming into the mic and rolling around on the floor.

33.description: What a great venue. They have cold beer.They have good music.They have been there a long time.Their block party this past year had some great music and interesting displays.It is distinctly urban, behind the city fueling station.It is exactly the same as the first time I was there 15 years ago.It is good. Go.

43.description: Nice place to catch some live music.  Last night I heard the improbable match up of Chicago singer songwriter honky tonk guitarist Robbie Fulks and the great Chicago Irish fiddler Liz Carroll.  This was likely a historic concert, as Liz said she'd never before played "old time" Appalachian music in her long career.The Hideout is aptly named.  It's on Wabansia, in an old industrial factory area, accessible from Elston Avenue.  I made the mistake of walking to Wabansia on Ashland, finding the Kennedy Expressway blocking my path, then having to backtrack down to North Avenue and over to Elston.  It's easy to get to after the first visit.The Hideout strikes me as a bar that could be plunked down in some little corner of Wisconsin and be quite at home.  It's a clapboard frame house-like building, with a few tables and chairs out front on a patio, with a very long bar at the front and a nice musical concert room in the back.  Lots of wood paneling and taxidermied giant fish on the walls.  Wisconsin.A very helpful and well used bicycle rack stood outside near the front. I had a $3.50 can of Shiner Bock.  Drafts like Gumball Head were $5, so it's not all hipster PBR cans here.  Cover for the music tonight was ten bucks, don't know if that changes per act.The show room was full, with many of us left standing.  A few high stools and high top tables along the sides and a hundred or more chairs arranged in rows theatre style in the center.  The open screen windows and giant ceiling fans did little to keep the crowd cool, even on a chilly night, so be warned to dress lightly here.  Even the performers commented on the sauna like conditions.  The sound mixing was good, not a single instance of feedback marred the show.  It was nice to see a few little kids here, enjoying the music with their parents, similar to a pub in Ireland.

2.description: One of the grooviest bars/venues in Chicago. Hidden away in a semi industrial area; but if you follow the neat signs you'll be just fine. No complaints on drink prices, the bartenders aren't generally chatty but quick to present you with your drink. The bar area does get pretty packed when you are attending a show here- not the biggest bar room area, but there are a few tables you can sit at if you are lucky. Not sure what the men's pisser situation is but the women's restroom is really nice. Never dirty. I LOVE the stage room. There's about 6 tables on each side of the room you can lounge at. The string lights on the ceiling have been one of my favorite things about this place, as well as the Hideout sign above the stage. Not to mention the killer fish decor hanging on the walls. Who doesn't want to go between staring at a mounted fish all the while watching whatever band you came to see perform. Hideout will forever have a special place in my heart and puts on some solid shows. I always look forward to psych fest!

18.description: Cheap drinks, rando shows, laid-back vibe.  These things are enough to earn five stars from this gal.  Somehow I always end up at some type of show here when I'm in town.   And its cool with me.  I'm a sucker for divey bars and divier performance spaces, so I totally dig this place.  Located within an industrial area, parking is a breeze.  Bonus: last time I went, some TV show was being shot outside, half a block down.  Yay for bright lights and the hope of seeing a famous face!

41.description: This is the quintessential Chicago bar. If you have friends coming in from out of town and you want to show them a real slice of Chicago away from tourism, this is the bar. I have been going there for years and never had a bad time there. Good people, good music, good comedy, cheap drinks, great atmosphere (if you like a good neighborhood bar). The location is not ideal for anyone to walk to, but that is part of the charm of the place. Plus, the Hideout Festival gets better and better every year. Love that there is outdoor space, and a bar away from the room with a perfect size stage (not too big, not too small) with good sound. I've always had great service there as well. This place is one of, if not the best bar in Chicago.

52.description: Hidden within an industrial area,  there is no way that you'd stumble upon this bar.  I found it while investigating Ada St (this would be a good spot to wrap up an evening).  The bar has had a liquor license since the 1890s, and the prices also bring your back to an earlier time...  Good beer and mixed drinks (you call it) were at the $5-6 range (quite a departure from the downtown area).  The staff is engaging and the crowd vibe is very chill.  This spot will not be noted for the interior decor, but it looks like what it is - a regular bar with cool people.  it The bar staff is very friendly and engaging.  The bands and activities are certainly a draw - most recently, I went for the WBEZ Interview Show which again, drew quite an assortment of people.  And that's why I'll return.

50.description: My band just played a show here and had a fantastic experience. The venue is intimate and beautiful (LOVE the Christmas lights strung across the ceiling) and there's a great selection of good, well-priced beer, such as $3 cans of 312. Bartenders are really friendly and do a great job dealing with the crowds and the sound is great, whether you're performing or an audience member. Fingers crossed that we get another show here!

4.description: The Hideout is an amazing venue.  Great booze selection, great atmosphere and great musical guests.  Have been to a couple shows, the Christmas-time sale, Hideout fest, and it never disappoints. Reasonable prices, solid service, good people.  If you have the opportunity - check it out!

6.description: This is an awesome bar to see excellent shows and meet great people! There is ALWAYS something happening so check out their calendar, I'm serious, it's worth it!If you haven't been to their soup & bread event on wednesdays (during the winter only), you HAVE to go! It's so awesome-you get all you can eat soup, bread, and sometimes dessert for a donation-based fee. I mean who doesn't love to get cozy with soup in the dead of winter!(Also, parking is easy to find for those that are driving, but kinda hard for those taking public transportation. Guess that's why it's called the Hideout-it really IS out in the middle of nowhere)

22.description: This is a hipster venue for sure.  :)  Laid back, interesting acts, strange location.  Pretty much sums it up.  I have only been here a couple of times, once for veggie bingo, and have enjoyed it both times.  Service is friendly and prices are reasonable.  The bingo was lots of fun.  The crowd was friendly and there were hot dogs and veggie dogs (hallelujah).  What else can I say about it?  It's a good time.  Come here to hang out.  Yeah.

15.description: The Hideout is one of several redeeming places of Chicago for me. You can go and be yourself among a bunch of other people who are doing the same. Granted, those other people might be weird, but if that's not your scene, you probably won't like it here. It's in an old house stuck in the middle of an industrial area, and it suits that location in a way.I've seen a couple of shows here whilst drinking organic cider under the ceiling covered in twinkle lights, and I will definitely be returning for more.

57.description: I adore the Hideout, although I'm the first to admit it's not for everyone. If you're more of a River North type bar person, you're not going to like this place. But if you like a chill, almost dive-y type bar with top notch music and comedy shows, then the Hideout is perfect for you! It's a bit off the beaten path, which helps keep some more annoying clientelle away (such as DePaul students with fake ids that are all over the Lincoln Park bar scene). They have great music almost every night of the week, along with some really fantastic reoccuring events, such as Soup & Bread, The Interview Show, a monthly dance party, and the Immediate Sound Series. They're cash only and there's easy parking if you drive or bike.

20.description: The Hideout is super divey bar that has been around since pre-Prohibition.  It is located in an industrial area, and I didn't even know it was there until living in Chicago for almost two years.  They have tons of events every month ranging from concerts to random benefits.  It's a pretty unique place off of the beaten trail.Last night, I met up with some friends to play veggie bingo.  Cards are $3 each or $10 for 4, and it benefits local community gardens.  They have free hot dogs donated by Hot Doug's and grand prize of lots of local veggies!  The hosts were quirky and funny, and I overall had a great time.The bartenders are quick to pour drinks and very friendly.  Keep in mind, this bar is cash only, and if you're taking a cab, you probably need to have the address handy because it's location is so obscure.

36.description: Cozy little venue. Very hidden. Great place to see a small show. Ok booze.

14.description: We went to this place for the first time last night with our friends. We did not know what to expect nor we had any idea of which type of music/artist were going to be there.We had such a great time!We are not hipsters, were older than most of the people and have different music taste but for some reason we loved this place. It is a very pleasant place, drinks are not expensive and people are friendly. We enjoyed being in an environment that was so different from what we are used to, nothing like having an open mind and let the world surprise you ;).

58.description: Tito's as the only vodka option?  Really?  It's awful if it is not YOUR vodka.  Why piss off your customer before they have even ordered.  My friend asked about gins and they said they had four or five.  I get the farm to table thing and it is well done, but Tito's is hardly at this point "farm to table".  Many better local pours (North Shore).  Food was good.  Trout good.  Bruschetta quite good.  Zeppolle was delish.  But just a bad start.  Service was excellent

56.description: I had really high hopes for this place after reading the menu, some reviews, and checking out the pics - but I have to say it came up a little short. First though, I will say the service and atmosphere were both 4-5 stars. The staff was friendly, attentive, and helpful. The owner (I believe) came over to check on my friend and I, and was very friendly and genuine. And the overall atmosphere was relax and friendly. I tend to have a problem hearing in restaurants but the music and "level of noise" was not an issue - which is always a huge plus in my book.As for the food, we tried the Diver Scallop Crudo, Meatball, Beef Carpaccio, Black Kale Spaghetti (1/2 size), and Mushroom Rotolo (1/2 size). The Crudo was my least favorite - the mix of scallop and chicharone was just a little strange flavor-wise to me. The Meatball and the Carpaccio were both a little one note, good, but just lacking something that makes it memorable. The Spaghetti was good when you got crumbles of cheese in the bit, but when you didn't it too was a little one note. The Rotolo was probably my favorite, I wasn't that familiar with the dish so I didn't quite know what to expect. It's on the subtle side but it has a good mix of textures and flavors so I really enjoyed it. I'd definitely go back to sample some of the cocktails and some other dishes before drawing any final conclusions (especially if the Black Pepper Rigatoni comes back since that seems to be the star of the joint), but after my recent experience I won't be chomping at the bit.

29.description: Charlatan is a great spot if you are looking for a laid back environment to take a date for a great dining experience. I enjoyed myself at Charlatan and will definitely be going back.Drinks* Civil Obedience - delicious and worth a try (4stars)* No Dignity, No Doubt - wasn't a fan of this because I don't like the taste of grapefruit, but the date liked it (3.5 stars)Food* Cheese Plate - was differently a pleasant surprise. Worth the $15 and would get it again (4 stars)* Grilled Octopus - you get a good serving size that's big enough for two people to share. Wasn't the best octopus I've had, but was good enough to eat it all (3.5 stars)* Black Pepper Rigatoni - is a must try! The wild boar mixed with the pepper and parmesan had my taste buds thinking Christmas had come up (5 stars)* Smoked Spaghetti Carbonara - the pork belly made this dish a must try (4 stars)

42.description: Went here last night with a couple of friends and we thought it was absolutely fabulous. The vibe is perfectly lively and trendy, the service is noteworthy, and the food is outstanding. Everything is great for sharing and we ordered over half of the menu items. I highly recommend the octopus, corn pasta, and grilled scallions. A great place for a fun date or dinner with friends!

23.description: I'm sitting here now writing this review, that's how good this restaurant is! Order a bunch of the half orders. Black Pepper Rigatoni is a must! ENJOY

47.description: Went due to reviews about awesome food on Yelp. However. Noise level was so high we could not hear ourselves talk or think and while the pasta was good we left to get dessert elsewhere. And this was starting at 7pm.

8.description: Came here for drinks after work and had a great time. I enjoyed my cocktail  ( civic disobedience) and my friend enjoyed her wine.  I was going to dinner after wards so We just shared the focaccia. it was crunchy on the outside and soft and moist  on the inside. the staff was friendly. Plus, as I was finishing my drink he came by and asked if I wanted another, so my glass was never empty. I would definitely come here again!

31.description: A lovely room and good service were unfortunately spoiled by an inconsistent meal--including one supremely bad dish.  Smoked spaghetti carbonara was nicely done with a perfect egg, though it was light on smoke, and the hunk of pork belly accompanying it was mostly unmelted fat--its flavor did not combine with the egg at all.  Hubby's octopus was quite tasty.For mains, my hubby quite enjoyed the pork collar.  I was looking forward to the chicken, particularly because it was accompanied by malfatti, a not often seen pasta.  Disappointingly, what I received was a single, large, sad malfatto, resembling a giant green turd on my plate.  It was dry, bland, and rather unappetizing--thankfully the chicken had flavor, though it was also overcooked.

34.description: i have been here like 4 times, which considering it is right by my house doesnt sound like a lot , but because i hate going to the same places repeatedly, it says a LOT. All the pastas are PERFECT, I've never gone wrong with any of the food choices here, including their desserts and cocktails - all made unique and to perfection. I love the ambiance, its got a romantic feel with just the right amount of hustle and bustle but so you can still talk intimately with whoever you took there. The bar area makes for a nice late night spot. But what you really need to know is that you HAVE to order the foccaccia. Its the perfect amount of crispy and crusty on the outside and perfectly sponge softness inside, salty and served with the most phenomenal butter my thighs have ever had the delight of enjoying. Do it and thank me later. YUM.

16.description: I've lived in the neighborhood for a few years and was a big fan of the fried chicken at West Town Tavern- the restaurant this spot used to house. In fact, I work with Alonso Sotelo who was the executive chef at WTT for 10 years! I am happy to report that Charlatan is an awesome restaurant and great addition to the neighborhood.We walked over on a snowy January Monday night for the 6PM reservation we'd made online. It got pretty busy so I'm glad we made that reservation! My girlfriend enjoyed her cocktail made with scotch, and the fact that two of the cocktails names begin with, "Don't..." She also loved her glass of red.For dinner we started with the beef carpaccio, which was excellently seasoned and complimented by crispy potatoes, and the grilled octopus, beautifully charred and given a hit of acid from romesco.  The big hit of the night, for me, the boring one, was the spaghetti and meatballs. The spicy red sauce and especially the meatballs were delicious.For dessert we had coffee, hot, and cold espresso poured over vanilla gelato- an affogato.  We ordered just about everything except the pig's head- 3 drinks, 2 appetizers, 2 full size pasta entrees and a side dish, dessert, and 2 coffees, and the total was just $100. Everything was done very well- the coziness of the room, the flawless service, the high level of execution from the kitchen.  I can't wait to get back to Charlatan!

13.description: For all the wannabe Bourdain's and Zimmern eaters in Chicago, Charlatan is the spot to PIG out starting with their signature dishes Pig Head and Oxtail, aptly named Heads and Tails.When I first read about this on the interwebs, I was so, so excited to checkout the Pig head! I'm all about weird eats and having eaten my share of pig offal, from stomach, tongue, intestines, feet, adding cheek, ears and eyeball to the list seems to be the natural progression.  It is not for the faint of heart, so I had to invite certain "key" friends to join me in tackling these dishes. You either love it or grossed out by it. And trust me, you need the help, these are large 14" full cast iron pans. The Pig came with a side of fingerling potatoes. Oxtail came with roasted crusty bread. Both are succulent, gelatinous, rich, fatty beautifully prepared meat. The old, meat falls off the bone is absolutely true. It needs to be. I love the roasted vegetables that came with it all, all cooked in the fat of the animal. Apples, vidalia onions and turnips never tasted SO GOOD. Rustic upscale. We also ordered one of the pasta dishes. Their claim to fame is that it's all made in house. Fabulous pasta - al dente, not to mention really interesting dish - black kale spaghetinni. The only disappointing item was the grilled octopus - it tasted like burnt ashes.Decor was dark, moody with animal heads with pretty wallpaper and a few curse words to boot, but it's in a foreign language, so it's totally acceptable... even artsy! Love this place, and I love that they know how to make food is so foreign I wouldn't really know how to cook it myself makes this place so cool. Come hungry.

11.description: highly recommend the pig head and the grilled octopusthe pig head is very satisfying, it might sound very exotic, but it is just very crisp pork skin with very rich pork meat underneath, if you have 4 or more ppl, definitely give it a try

39.description: Food is pretty good and if I lived in the area, looks like a place I'd hang out at.

37.description: Service was good, wine was good, salad was good. I don't understand the chef's choice of serving the fish with a funnel cake. Usually a person who orders fish is looking to eat something lighter. Serving a nice piece of fish on top of a huge elephant ear is baffling to me. The succotash would have been enough, maybe with some greens. The kale pasta was good but oily. Peaches and cream dessert was solid. I really don't get the decor--it's a bit all over the place, with industrial style, taxidermy (can we be over the taxidermy thing already, Chicago hipsters?!), and kitchy skull wallpaper. Made me really miss West Town Tavern, which was one of my favorite places to have a consistently good, clean dinner in Chicago without all the hoopla.

0.description: It's always fun checking out a neighborhood restaurant that really has a neighborhood feel to it. From the outside, Charlatan may appear to be another snobby faux industrial "gastropub" but it's truly far from that. You can expect quality dishes from enthusiastic servers who absolutely care about the drinks and meals they're providing. I started my night off with a lion's tale, I had had one last week from Bar Marta for the first time and have been hooked on em ever since. Lol I didn't know they were considered a classic drink - so the bartender effortlessly whipped me one up. It was rich and a bit darker than I remembered, but I absolutely enjoyed it. Next up I had the grilled rapini and goat cheese stuffed chicken breast. I really wanna emphasize how well these two dishes paired together. Was in total awe with how tender and sweet the grilled rapini was. Never would I have imagined that combination of flavors from a grilled vegetable. Anything with goat cheese is right up my alley, so naturally the goat cheese stuffed chicken breast was absolutely screaming my name. Swimming on top of a bed of sweat roasted garlic risotto I actually thought I was in heaven. I could eat these two dishes every night. Coming back here again ASAP.

38.description: Black kale spaghetti - fantastic! Never a bad experience at Charlatan. So happy this has become a staple in the neighborhood.

51.description: I had an inventive chicken parm sandwich with fontina, savory tomato sauce and arugula on a brioche.  The carbonara with pork belly was both understated AND satisfied my need for thick eggy noodles and a gorgeous piece of belly.  They do a lot of interesting things with poached eggs (the carbonara and the bruschetta feature egg prominently).  The tater tots area all over the menu, but I did not think they were as special as the other food.  They're good but, I mean, at the end of the day, its a tater tot. I will add that they make a great bloody mary.

27.description: This may be my new favorite Italian place in Chicago. Have been here 3-4 times and liked it but this past Friday was really excellent. My guest and I shared the meatballs (which had a very nice kick to them), the focaccia, and half orders of the black pepper rigatoni and corn rotolo. Everything was great, including the reasonably priced bottle pinot noir they recommended.  All this for a quite reasonable $112. The decor and atmosphere may not be your typical Italian restaurant fare, but is interesting and a tad edgy. The service was also excellent. All in all, Charlatan is earning a spot at the very top of my Chicago restaurant list.

32.description: I just moved to the neighborhood and wanted to try this place. I was impressed with the overall experience. The menu is well thought out, food composition was sophisticated, the wait staff was attentive and the atmosphere is romantic.I had the Octopus & Black Pepper Rigatoni, both were fantastic! The waiter was on point with wine pairings for our meal. (Of course I started the night w/a "Old Fashionish")I'd recommend this place to anyone who is looking for a romantic night for 2 or intimate friends dinner party outside of River North who wants to the same dining experience.

54.description: A+ food and drinks. We trusted our waiter and we were not disappointed. A must eat. The Civil Obedience from the bar was unique and delicious. The mushroom messinese  was the table favorite.

48.description: It's small, intimate, with amazingly attentive service. meatballs = order the focaccia.  Actually, just order the focaccia in general.  You won't regret it.  But get them together.  Ah-MAZING.  Also, the meatballs are pretty fantastic. The Peas were awesome. I like peas--I like they don't kill the peas.  We got the diver scallops as an app.  Solid.Got the bolognese special. Again. Awesome. EVOO Salted cod ravioli?  F*CKING AMAZING.Eat here.  Drink here.  Be happy.  and get the damn bread.

44.description: Let me tell you a couple of three things. We are absolutely in love with The Charlatan. Anthony really does a great job of making everyone feel comfortable at his home.  He's quick witted and quite personable which makes the experience all the more enjoyable. Our server, Scott gave us amazing recommendations throughout the evening and used his best discretion in staggering out the meal. His attention to detail and intuition allows you to enjoy all the amenities of five star service in this charming space.  I could go on and on...Do yourself a service and stop by The Charlatan. TL;DR:Ambiance: ****Food: ****Service: ****Drinks: ****

24.description: One of my favorite brunch spots in the city. A great option if you're looking to mix it up a little bit as they include some breakfast staples but also offer some amazing pastas and other unique choices. I couldn't pick a favorite brunch entree if I tried because everything is so high quality and delicious. Their cocktail menu is also great!

7.description: After seeing droolworthy photo stream pics of meals here by 2 of my cousins on separate occasions, I decided it was time I trek over to Charlatan for some homemade pasta!Charlatan's got a date night-y/girls' night out vibe and some unique cocktails.  I enjoyed my citrus-y Civil Disobedience drink.  My eyes and heart were set on the black pepper rigatoni, especially after reading a handful of raving reviews on it.  It was good, but I thought my friends' black kale spaghettini was GREAT!  I will definitely get a full order of the spaghettini when I return.  So comforting and flavorful.Dessert was so-so.  My BFF ordered passionfruit sorbet, which I didn't have, since I think passionfruit tastes like how armpit/BO smells, but I did have my fair share of the chocolate donuts with caramel dipping sauce.  The choc munchkins were a little dense and flour-y, but the caramel sauce really made the dish, and yes, we ate it by the plain spoonful!I estimate the dining area seats 60 or so people.  Note: the chairs aren't the comfiest.  +100 on OpenTable.

49.description: We were here on Saturday 7/18 at around 7pm. The 4-stars I give is for the food, beverage selection and for Devin, the bartender. Devin was fantastic, very professional and knowledgeable.  As far as the hostess and the manager goes, there was a lot to be desired. When we arrived at the restaurant the hostess told us we could not sit at the high tables by the bar as I requested because they were reserved for larger parties (more than 2 people). So my boyfriend and I sat at the bar. Right after we sat at the bar we saw the hostess sit not one but three couples on the high tables we had requested earlier. Very disappointing!  As far as the manager for that night, I saw him asking every table around how everything was except for us. I commend Devin as he is the only one that represents the restaurant image for high standards and also commend the chef because the food was fantastic!

40.description: I have to say that I was stunned at the prices here when I first looked at the menu.  However, the half portions are plenty for a meal, and are very reasonable.  I still think the entrée prices are high for Noble Square.  Hell would freeze over before I paid $28 for a piece of chicken, no matter whose farm it came off of.  The rock shrimp appetizer is delicious, and the pate was perfect--served with warm strawberries with mustard and balsamic--really creative.  The cocktails were delicious, and the black pepper rigatoni with boar ragu was really good.  We split a tiramisu, and it was awesome--much drier and more substantial than is typical.  I'd definitely go back.

53.description: It took 40 minutes for a awful cocktail (with 5 people in the entire restaurant).  The bartender was a complete jerk, yet totally  intrigued in finding an iPad cord.  Don't waste your time in the bad service!  After a 40 minute wait for cocktails, who knows if the food is good.

30.description: Charlatan was probably 3.5 stars on my first visit, but since we came back about 9 months later they have sure stepped up their game. There wasn't one thing I didn't like!! The servers are the nicest food loving hipsters out there, and they aren't satisfied unless you leave happy. Basically, if you went there when they first opened and weren't impressed--give it another try. You won't be sorry!*recommendations*-Grill Octopus - best grilled octopus I've ever had-Pan fried trout-Black pepper rigatoni-focaccia

46.description: Charlatan is my favorite restaurant in this neighborhood. We've been many times for brunch and finally made it yesterday for dinner. Everything we've had is just spot on, they really know what they're doing back there on the kitchen. Standout items include any of the pastas. They make the pasta in house and cook it perfectly al dente. We've tried the carbonara, the mushroom rotolo, and the black kale spaghettini and they are all great. Flavors are all really well balanced. The trout we had was simple and yet not at the same time. The grilled octopus was cooked perfectly tender. All the dishes are seasonal and colorful which I always appreciate. For brunch, whatever you try just make sure you also get either a side of tots or the mushroom scrapple tots.Good drink menu as well. Bf enjoyed his old fashioned, and I got a watermelon wheat beer from a San Francisco brewery cuz it's #summer!The only thing I didn't like here was the dessert unfortunately. We got the tiramisu, and although I didn't mind that it wasn't a standard tiramisu, it was just kinda meh and there was way too much rum in the mascarpone. If you're gonna mess with a dessert as perfect as classic tiramisu, it should be amazing and unfortunately it was not.Still, I love the food at Charlatan and have recommended it to everyone I know and will definitively be back!

1.description: We've dined at the various restaurants that have occupied this space over many years, so were curious to try Charlatan. We hand a good time. The game-inflected menu is compact, but has many good choices that are just a little different from other Italian-themed places. The cooking was generally quite good, too. And there's a decent list of Italian wines that includes many affordable choices.VIBE: Rustic, gamy (e.g., the heads hanging on the walls), quirky light fixtures. Welcoming vibe from the host to the server and runners. A bit dimly lit for me, but we found a satisfactory table. A bit noisy, but it was only about half-full, so conversation was possible.SERVICE: Friendly, knowledgeable and helpful. Server was attentive, but not hovering or intrusive.GOOD: Clearly, the kitchen knows what it's doing. Housemade pastas were delicious and perfectly cooked. My rabbit casoncelli was rich and nicely plated. My companion's special black truffle pappardelle was also delicious. Sage brown butter sauce was nicely brown -- not just melted butter as in some places. Seasoning balance was very good, and not over-salted. Escarole salad with arugula pesto vinaigrette was loaded with goodies (bacon, walnuts, beets) and so yummy. For dessert, affogato was perfect, with strong, rich espresso and a generous scoop of good gelato.NOT SO GOOD: I wish it was a little brighter and a little quieter, but no big deal.We're looking forward to coming back to try other things. Based on this one visit, it's definitely a neighborhood gem.

55.description: My husband and I were walking by here on Friday night around 6 or so and decided to try it out. The restaurant wasn't busy yet, with just a few tables full, but by the time we left, the place was hopping. We really liked the atmosphere and the feeling of the place. It felt special yet casual. We had the octopus, daily pate, daily Bolognese (half order, it was a squid ink spaghetti), and the pan fried trout. Everything was absolutely delicious. Normally, we always have a dish where we feel like it shined in comparison with the others, but we really enjoyed all 4 things that we ordered. The cocktails were also tasty. I had a civil obedience and my husband had an old fashionish. I also had a "no dignity, no doubt" and the first few sips felt a little gin heavy, but the drink really grew on me. Our only complaint would be that the cocktails were a bit slow coming out. We received some of our food before we received our cocktails. However, we will be back to try the pig's head.

9.description: I thought Charlatan was fantastic.  That's not just because they have postcards of their taxidermied, mounted animal heads, though it doesn't hurt.  I should have scooped up more of those.  I need to work on my correspondence.  The cocktails were great, particularly the Jeppson's Swizzle, combining my many loves; carrot, passion fruit, crushed ice, and yes, malort.  It sounds questionable, I know, but it really was delicious.  Like a negroni or perhaps falling in love with a vampire, it has a bite that you get used to over time.The food was equally good.  They have either half or full sized portions of their pastas, and frankly a shared salad and a half size each for the two of us was plenty, but if you've got a big appetite, go for the gusto or share a bunch of little things.  We shared an escarole salad with peas, farro, pesto and some other things on it which I enjoyed.  We got the lardons on the side because my companion is veg. so I got to reap double the benefits of those.  He tried a black kale spaghetti dish which was gone in a flash, and I found the black pepper rigatoni with wild boar ragu to be incredible.  I also added a meatball which was dense and had a kick to it.  I didn't need that meatball, but yeah I did.  The marinara served with it was very nice as well.We were too crammed with food for dessert (and had a date with Miko's Italian Ice already) but perhaps on a future visit, which there will definitely be.

26.description: My boyfriend and I came here after months of anticipation- looking forward to a great, new addition to the neighborhood. We showed up a few minutes before 7pm on a Friday night (to a bar that was 1/3 full and the restaurant not even half full). We were given a 1.5 hour wait because we had no reservations.  We found this unusually long for a restaurant that wasn't even full and it was before 7.  We accepted this wait and went to the bar.....and continued to wait at the bar...for an hour and a half. At no point in the evening were the bar or restaurant ever full. The atmosphere and food were okay. It's hard to understand how we can have a shorter wait at Chicago staples like Longman & Eagle or Au Cheval with better food? Charlatan- if you want to become a neighborhood favorite- you have to allow two people to walk in to a restaurant and be seated in a reasonable amount of time...especially when you never filled all of your tables.

25.description: highly recommend the pig head and the grilled octopusthe pig head is very satisfying, it might sound very exotic, but it is just very crisp pork skin with very rich pork meat underneath, if you have 4 or more ppl, definitely give it a try

12.description: I love the ambiance and the way this place is designed. We came here in Dec for my birthday. Its definitely cozy for a winter night.We started with some cocktails and a cider. They were delicious! I can't remember what I had. Something brown, maybe a Manhattan? My boyfriend tried the Run the Julip. It was refreshing! The online menu is different than the menu that they had that night. One big difference is that everyone raves about the octopus but it was not on the menu. Maybe its seasonal? So we had the daily bread. I was pretty yummy! Lots of cheese and good olive oil.My boyfriend and best friend had the fried chicken and waffles. They have it on Mondays in honor of the previous restaurant that used to do that. There were 2 clean plates and no one offered me a bite so I assume it was delicious. I had the app size pasta. Its not on the online menu. It was cheesy and yummy. I do have a bit of a hard time with this restaurant because its very meaty. I like that a lot of their dishes are offered in a half size so you can mix and try things.For dessert we had the pecan pie. It was unlike any other pecan pie that I've had in that the filling was not like a jelly custard. It was super sugary, crunchy, and really good.The service was great. Helpful but not hovering.I'll have to come back for the octopus with the beef braised carrots on the side.

59.description: This place is great! My husband and I went for a date night and loved it! Definitely get the pastas, they are all made in-house and fantastic! We will definitely be back!

21.description: Don't go here.  What a joke.  Have no idea if the food is any good because I couldn't even get any.  They don't respect a reservation.  Had an 8pm reservation and after 50 minutes and 3 times telling us "tables are having desert" there was still no sign of a table and nothing but "sorry".  Left the restaurant, walked down the block, grabbed beers and wine at Lush and had a great meal at Shaman.

17.description: My girlfriend and I ate here for the first time and for Valentine's Day. Making a reservation was painless with an online system, and the restaurant double checked shortly before our reserved time to make sure we were still planning on coming. We arrived a bit early, but were still promptly seated. Our server had a great attitude and was prompt with drink orders as well as with checking in on us. The food came out in decent time, and all of the dishes were fantastic. The prices were within reason as well, and we definitely plan on visiting again. I went the route of getting a couple of half dishes & then splitting another half dish so that I could have a few different things.

10.description: My friends took me here for my birthday in March.  I like vaguely remember eating at whatever the previous restaurant was in this space, but I liked how the current owners transformed the place, including the industrialized decor.We ordered a lot of food and shared it family style!  Starters including the daily foccacia with the yummy roasted garlic butter and a little on the salty side with the Maldon, but still good.  The cheese plate was underwhelming, I wish the bread that came with it was better than just toast.  The Meatball had a definite kick to it.  the Grilled Octopus was standard fare, also a little on the salty side.  My favorite entree was the Black Kale Spaghettini, a nice blend of flavors and textures.  Second was the Black Pepper Rigatoni. Pasta was cooked right.  The 1/2 Guinea Hen was moist, but I didn't really care for the celery root gratin and the pomegranate threw me off.  For dessert we had some sort of caramel budino which was good, but not mind-blowing.I wish I had a chance to try out a cocktail since it looks like they make pretty good drinks and have a good selection of beers, but will have to wait until after the baby arrives.  Also, they have Fried Chicken and Waffles Mondays from 5-10pm! Who wouldn't return for that?

5.description: We had a wonderful meal there on Friday night; it was busy, vibrant, with some great service.Apps:1. The grilled octopus: Extremely tender octopus, with beer braised carrots. Wonderful Dish. It's one of the most popular dishes on the menu for good reason.  The octopus was on point. Soft and with a nice grilled crisp.2. The meatballs:  They are large. One can feed two people. They are a good mix of meats with a tender texture. The sauce is the winner though. It has a little kick so beware, but it's delicious. Pasta: The black pepper rigatoni was really good. The pasta was al dente, with a good ragu sauce.  I would give this one a 4 out of 5 because the flavor could have been deeper, but overall very good.The Big Meats: Beware there is a ton of food here. 1. The Pork Shank - was amazing. The meat was fall off the bone and extremely flavorful. There is a lot of fat on it though (which is why the meat is so good), but delicious piece. It comes with noodles (kind of like linguine), beets, and a duck egg. All fantastic. 2. The Whole Chicken Parm. Probably the best chicken parm I've ever had. However at $67, it better be! Haha!  It was like having a heavenly chicken pizza.  The chicken comes as a flattened out piece that is massive. Great sauce and cheese, served over a bed of angel hair with marinara sauce and a huge bowl of  salad.  Awesome! Really!  Was it worth $67?  maybe? but it's a dish you'll remember and be happy with. Wines: We had two bottles of red that was excellent accompaniments to our meal. Overall tres magnifique!  Excellent work Charlatan. We'll be back!

3.description: I'm ever so slightly traumatized by seeing three of my male friends dig into a pig's head and tear Wilbur apart to his skull, breaking bones, exposing teeth, jiggling around the nose....ahhhhhh! My friend has been talking about getting this meal for month's so I'm glad he finally got to satiate his appetite. It was a cool experience to order a giant pig head and I'll admit the meat was quite delicious but for me that's a one and done thing! I don't think I could handle the dissection again. Aside from the pig's head ($60 and they say it feeds two but it fed 4 of us well with a bunch of sides), dinner included interesting dishes and most were delicious. They have some standout pastas that are pricey but quite filling!Black Kale Spaghetti ($21 for full size) - Kale & Walnut Pesto, Butternut Squash Chips, & blue cheese. I was angry I had to share this dish because the it was packed with taste and had me experiencing new flavor combinations I loved.Black Pepper Rigatoni ($25 for full size) - Wild Boar Ragu, Parmesan and brussel sprouts - It packs a punch! Delicious with a tiny bit of spice that lingers, but was just the right amount for me.If you are doing the pig's head or their duck to share with friends, I highly recommend getting a couple of their pastas to split, as well. They are money.The daily foccacia ($5) is some tasty bread but for the amount of butter they include, we would have loved a bit more bread. So much wasted, tasty, soft, garlic butter.Our server recommended the Grilled Octopus ($13) dish saying it was the most popular on the menu. Makes sense because that was some soft octopus unlike I've ever had before with a good char on it. It came with an array of ingredients we had major issues identifying but they all went together well & my whole group loved the plate.Charlatan's food and service was good enough that I will be back and try more on their menu!  It's Italian with a new and interesting twist, fun new combinations of ingredients and just downright tasty.

35.description: I had a wonderful experience dining here the other night. It was my last night in Chicago after 3 full days of tours so I wanted to treat myself to a nice Italian meal. This place looked perfect on yelp and then I discovered it was only 4 blocks from where I was staying! I called ahead and they were so friendly and I was treated like a queen from start to finish. I wish I knew everyone involved's names to give credit,  but the entire staff was welcoming and warm. I pigged out and had mushroom pasta w pork belly ragout (on special) grilled green beans w mint and feta (excellent and was lovely w the pasta dish believe it or not) and fresh ciabatta. Only wish I'd had room for dessert. A nice upscale neighborhood place that I will definitely return to on my next trip to Chicago:-)

19.description: Charlatan is one of my favorite restaurants in the city of Chicago right now! Love it here. Located in West Town on Chicago Avenue, it's got a great view of Eckert Park, and in the summertime, they open up all the front windows to views of the greenery. This place has a perfectly laid-back atmosphere with courteous wait staff who seem to enjoy working there. I've never been when it's overly crowded, but it always has a nice little buzz. Great place to have a conversation or a date night, etc. because you can actually hear what your fellow diners are saying. The food here is truly superb. I love the spin they put on traditional Italian dishes, and I love even more than you can order a 1/2 size pasta portion! The carbonara is amazing-- a twist on the traditional style, they actually separate each ingredient out, and then you have the utensils at your table to mix them all in. Their drinks are also fantastic. GO!

28.description: This is my kind of place.  It's sophisticated with a casual feel.  All the dishes are approachable and well executed.   If I lived in the area, I could see myself eating here weekly.  It's that good!We were lucky enough to come on a Monday where they do their Chicken and Waffle special.  Trust me, come on a Monday and order-you won't be disappointed.  Three bone in chicken thighs perfectly fried over a great waffle.  Housemade hot sauce and maple syrup to drizzle.  Amazing!Of course the meal didn't start or end there.  For appetizers, we tried the grilled octopus and the oft reviewed focaccia.  The octopus was some of the best I have tried.  Fork tender with a great char on it.  While others rave about the focaccia, I was not as big of a fan.  Unlike others, Charlatan's has a crispy crust but ours was perhaps a little too well done.  Not terrible but not something I would come back solely for.Charlatan makes their pastas in house so we had to try a few.  We opted for the smokled spaghetti carbonara and the black pepper rigatoni with wild boar ragu. Both were outstanding and I would struggle picking a favorite amongst the two.If you haven't been here yet, try it.  You won't be disappointed!

45.description: Brought my girlfriend here for her birthday. Super cute place. Very friendly and informed staff. Sampled several dishes but had to leave early. They were more than willing to oblige us. The steak was cooked expertly and the pasta! It's the news. They aren't afraid of flavor & spice here. I mean that in the best way possible. I suggest you make you way over. Ps our server Kevin was superb. Thank charlatan

33.description: First of all, the focaccia was the best bread I've ever had, hands down. Drinks were solid, as was the rest of our food. They were able to work with me as a vegetarian, which earns them many points in my book. It's a cute little spot. The only downside is that it is a bit loud inside, but that just means everyone is enjoying themselves there :)

43.description: The charcuterie board was great! Not going to fill you up, but a well out together starter. Decent cocktail creations, not limited to a specific genre or region. They apparently have a pigs head you can order in the menu. I never got it, but it is somewhat unique to this spot.

2.description: The warm and intimate ambiance at Charlatan is a welcome environment on a chilly Chicago night! First stop was the bar for a pre-dinner cocktail. The cocktail list was short, but each drink was totally unique and an eclectic mix of ingredients. I tried the Traveling Dunk Tank, made of Mezcal, Averna, Applejack, cider, black pepper and caramel. I had pasta for dinner, and the half size was perfect (along with a tasty and very spicy meatball on the side, and a few shared appetizers). Everyone in my party ordered separate pastas and they were each delicious. One of the specials was grated black truffle that could be added to any dish. As much as I love truffles, I wasn't ready to shill out an additional $28 to add it to my pasta... When I'm rich and famous I'll return and have all the truffle that my little heart desires! Overall, the food was tasty and the ambiance was lovely. Charlatan is a great place for a date or intimate dinner with friends.

18.description: Charlatan is my favorite restaurant in this neighborhood. We've been many times for brunch and finally made it yesterday for dinner. Everything we've had is just spot on, they really know what they're doing back there on the kitchen. Standout items include any of the pastas. They make the pasta in house and cook it perfectly al dente. We've tried the carbonara, the mushroom rotolo, and the black kale spaghettini and they are all great. Flavors are all really well balanced. The trout we had was simple and yet not at the same time. The grilled octopus was cooked perfectly tender. All the dishes are seasonal and colorful which I always appreciate. For brunch, whatever you try just make sure you also get either a side of tots or the mushroom scrapple tots.Good drink menu as well. Bf enjoyed his old fashioned, and I got a watermelon wheat beer from a San Francisco brewery cuz it's #summer!The only thing I didn't like here was the dessert unfortunately. We got the tiramisu, and although I didn't mind that it wasn't a standard tiramisu, it was just kinda meh and there was way too much rum in the mascarpone. If you're gonna mess with a dessert as perfect as classic tiramisu, it should be amazing and unfortunately it was not.Still, I love the food at Charlatan and have recommended it to everyone I know and will definitively be back!

41.description: the perfect dinner hands down. this evening we had a reservation for 6:15 and had the honor of Daniella, Sparkle Pony, waiting on us. PS. If you can request a waiter - choose her! she attends the table at decent times and knows the menu very well.we ordered two red wines, the cheese platter, smoked carbonara, and the rigatoni. all classics and all made perfectly. thank you for the wonderful experience Sparkle Pony - I will be back to see you!

52.description: Brought some out of town guests to this nice spot. The service was great and the restaurant is beautifully decorated and very hip. We split 3 pastas, the cheese plate and focaccia bread. The pastas were all delicious and very unique/unlike any other dishes I'd had recently. My personal favorite was the kale pasta. I'll definitely be back!

50.description: Charlatan is one of my favorite restaurants in the city of Chicago right now! Love it here. Located in West Town on Chicago Avenue, it's got a great view of Eckert Park, and in the summertime, they open up all the front windows to views of the greenery. This place has a perfectly laid-back atmosphere with courteous wait staff who seem to enjoy working there. I've never been when it's overly crowded, but it always has a nice little buzz. Great place to have a conversation or a date night, etc. because you can actually hear what your fellow diners are saying. The food here is truly superb. I love the spin they put on traditional Italian dishes, and I love even more than you can order a 1/2 size pasta portion! The carbonara is amazing-- a twist on the traditional style, they actually separate each ingredient out, and then you have the utensils at your table to mix them all in. Their drinks are also fantastic. GO!

4.description: Charlatan is a great spot if you are looking for a laid back environment to take a date for a great dining experience. I enjoyed myself at Charlatan and will definitely be going back.Drinks* Civil Obedience - delicious and worth a try (4stars)* No Dignity, No Doubt - wasn't a fan of this because I don't like the taste of grapefruit, but the date liked it (3.5 stars)Food* Cheese Plate - was differently a pleasant surprise. Worth the $15 and would get it again (4 stars)* Grilled Octopus - you get a good serving size that's big enough for two people to share. Wasn't the best octopus I've had, but was good enough to eat it all (3.5 stars)* Black Pepper Rigatoni - is a must try! The wild boar mixed with the pepper and parmesan had my taste buds thinking Christmas had come up (5 stars)* Smoked Spaghetti Carbonara - the pork belly made this dish a must try (4 stars)

6.description: After two bites, my wife commented that the pasta reminded her of what we had in Italy.  The pasta here is made in house, and it is thinner and more delicate.  This allows you to taste the ingredients of the dish.  We got three half portions so we could try different pastas.  Hands down, in our opinion, the Squid Ink Lumache was our favorite.  Service by Danielle  was awesome, with her suggestions, we had a great dinner.  The drink menu is innovative, but I enjoyed their version of the Old-Fashioned. Cannot wait to return!

22.description: Really lousy experience at Charlatan (my fourth visit and by far the worst). Our group was seated at a table that was far too small for the number of people in the party. When I asked the host about this, she said "we always do this" (not helpful), but at the very end of the meal a manager belatedly acknowledged what they had done. Service was lousy and slow. Drinks didn't arrive together for each person in our group, and neither did the food. The food was tasty but lukewarm after sitting out too long before being served. Won't be back anytime soon.

15.description: Came here with my wife and a friend.We had the grilled octopus to start.  The cook on the octopus was perfect, very tender with a light char on the outside.  The baby carrots were very savory and could have been an appetizer on their own!All three of us had pastas and they were each tasty in their own way.  I had the black pepper rigatoni, wife had the squid ink lumache, and friend had the rabbit casoncelli.

57.description: After seeing droolworthy photo stream pics of meals here by 2 of my cousins on separate occasions, I decided it was time I trek over to Charlatan for some homemade pasta!Charlatan's got a date night-y/girls' night out vibe and some unique cocktails.  I enjoyed my citrus-y Civil Disobedience drink.  My eyes and heart were set on the black pepper rigatoni, especially after reading a handful of raving reviews on it.  It was good, but I thought my friends' black kale spaghettini was GREAT!  I will definitely get a full order of the spaghettini when I return.  So comforting and flavorful.Dessert was so-so.  My BFF ordered passionfruit sorbet, which I didn't have, since I think passionfruit tastes like how armpit/BO smells, but I did have my fair share of the chocolate donuts with caramel dipping sauce.  The choc munchkins were a little dense and flour-y, but the caramel sauce really made the dish, and yes, we ate it by the plain spoonful!I estimate the dining area seats 60 or so people.  Note: the chairs aren't the comfiest.  +100 on OpenTable.

20.description: Had a reservation for 4 people on a Saturday night and we were left waiting at the bar for an hour although we kept asking if our table is ready. We decided to leave because they wouldn't honor our reservation so we never got to try the food.

36.description: AMAZING.  Went with a group of 6 last night and can't say one dish of the 8 we ordered was less than perfect.  Service was good, our server was around just enough to take care of our food and drink needs but didn't hover and the host (manager maybe?) was fab.  We went the family-style route and ordered the octopus (x2), foccacia (x2), black kale spaghetti, trout, rigatoni, sweet corn rotolo, and escarole salad (x2).  It was the perfect amount of food for leaving full/satisfied but not hating ourselves.  Enjoy!

14.description: This is the former West Town Tavern. The inside looks similar but even nicer. We were less adventurous than others and did not get the Pig Head or the Oxtail. However we did get the Focaccia, the charred Octopus, half orders of the Kale spaghetti, the black pepper penne, lobster risotto and several Old Fashionish, that's what they call it. Everything was really good! As others have mentioned, the pasta is hand made and fresh. 5 stars for Half orders. Service was excellent! My only 2 gripes - The food was a little oily and the location is not ideal. Overall 4.5 stars being upped to 5.

0.description: Love the drink Seksi. The flavor is just right and satisfying to your carbonated taste buds cravings. I was a huge soda drinker but after a scare with all of the sodas,and energy drinks I found seksi. This is a great drink when you want to replenish your system from all of the important elements you need and settle your carbonation cravings. I found out that they have these essential items in the drink. * Pearl Powder. .great for your skin and a source of calcium. * over 35 amino acids* 15 calories* it has less sugar than a cup of green teaThis is also a great mixer for alcoholic beverages!  I am a huge fan and I am glad I  came across this product and because I kicked soda to the curb I have lost 8lbs just by doing so and substituting my beverage with seksi instead of soda.I order my products on Www.drinkpearlaqua.com

3.description: My husband and I stopped in to Stock for lunch and it was awesome! He had a delicious pastie, which not only met the high expectations of our northern Michigan roots, but also improved upon what we expected because the chef nailed the pastry crust. YUM. I was craving veggies and had a perfect green, crunchy sandwich with arugula, cucumbers, and cream cheese. Best of all, we found out we could take some frozen pasties home with us for those week nights that we're too busy to cook. Can't recommend this place enough - it's fresh and local stuff from people who care (they're all really nice) and in a fun environment. Do it!

1.description: Brunch was great.  Surprised it wasn't crowded-  was here on a Saturday morning around 10:30, ordered with no wait, and had our food within minutes.  Also saw that they are BYOB.  Can't wait to come back.  Food was fantastic, service was friendly and quick.  Best of all they are farm to table.   Also there was free parking available.  No issue finding a spot.

2.description: What a find!  Stumbled upon this place for lunch after attending a baby yoga class.  Serving some of the best farm to table food - really fresh ingredients with a constantly changing menu. Chef Abra Berens does a fantastic job bringing together seasonal flavors. When I was in (now a couple months ago) I had a grilled peach sandwich with bacon as well as one of the recommended treats for dessert with fabulous seasonal berries. Everything tastes great. Would definitely make a point to come back again.

0.description: From the quality of food to the delivery, this place is great. I loved my split pea soup here and the bread and cheese was phenomenal. Really clean too and a nice space.

28.description: Dovetail would be a fabulous addition to any Chicago neighborhood but that stretch of Chicago Ave. is certainly overdue for a boutique of this caliber.  You can't help but wander in when you see its unique and quirky ever-changing window displays.  The space is lovely and the fare is even better.  Whether you are searching for women, men, jewelry, furniture, odd knickknacks, or one of a kind presents you will not be disappointed.  The owners have impeccable taste and their excitement and love for vintage pieces is evident.  Go!  Shop!

1.description: Dovetail carries a great mix of vintage and local designers.  You'll find accessories, clothing, jewelry, decanters, and so much more.  The shop is organized and inviting.  You'll discover fun finds for him and her!I've only been to one of their trunk shows but it seems like they showcase local designers.  This is a huge plus for me since I like buying locally made or USA made items.  Additionally, each time I've been in, there is always new merchandise.The owner is always engaging and helpful.  If you can't find what you're looking for during your visit, she'll even suggest a few other shops that might have what you need.So if you're in the market for something vintage, unique, or just wanting a browse, head over to Dovetail.  I'm sure you'll find something perfect for your needs.  I'll definitely be back!

9.description: I started going to dovetail when they opened.  Julie the owner has always been so sweet and helpful.  I love their inventory and feel right at home whenever I stop in.  If you are looking for some great vintage finds and cool jewelry from local designers I would say def stop by and see what they have.  You will not be disappointed. :)

23.description: In the interest of saving time, I'm not going to beat around the bush about this place. It's fantastic and worth all five of the stars I'm attributing to it. Under what criteria am I deciding them five star worthy you ask? I'm reviewing them on the basis of decor, selection, service, and price. Dovetail inhabits a an open, airy space, with a big picture window, and carefully edited racks of clothing along the left and right walls and well preserved mid-century furniture and accessories bisecting the room. The decor is visually interesting and provides multiple anchor areas full of color and pattern that coincide with the arrangement of merchandise. That's a plus and a nuance that I've see in few boutiques in Chicago. And if it's neglected in high end boutiques to say it's been overlooked in most vintage stores is an understatement. Dovetail operates in a rarefied strata on their decor. Onward. Dovetails is again rarefied in its careful attention to selecting pieces that won't be found just anywhere. In this respect, it's in the company of Silver Moon, which is another place where you just know, you have the only piece still extant and in good condition. Unlike Silver Moon, you have a larger selection of unique pieces that are actually wearable in different situations. Believe me I'm still wearing the cream knee length halter dress with gold embroidery that I bought from Dovetail, but not the periwinkle petticoat I got from SM. Now I have to admit here, that I'm not the hippest, coolest, super tiny hipster to ever to exist. In fact, I'm a documented non hipster; I mock mercilessly. I've never been to Pitchfork. I don't wear odd pieces layered on one another and no I've never lived in Wicker Park. I hold down a job in Internet Sales, am a solid size 8, and know I have some of the lamest, friends around since we drink non ironic labels of beer, host dinner parties, garden, and watch baseball games. The reason you must know all of this, is not that I'm missing out on my therapy sessions, but because the people I've encountered at Dovetail have been some of the nicest shopkeepers I've encountered anywhere (and I travel a bit). I love vintage clothing and always have. What I've become accustomed to is going into a vintage store, where I wander aimlessly throughout, pulling out one by one to discern sizing and price, and pretty much not being spoken to until I make it to the counter three hours later with one item to buy. At Dovetail, I was immediately greeted, allowed to wander for a few minutes, then asked if I needed help or had "anything specific in mind I was looking for" (and yes that's a direct quote I remembered since it was the first time anyone in a vintage store or boutique ever asked it to me), then when I answered I needed help I received it. Simple as that. Because surviving vintage pieces always tend to be skinny minnie size, the owner?/sales associate, looked me over, walked to a rack (color arranged), sifted instinctively passed all the colors that with suck with my mocha choca latte skin tone and brought out the aforementioned cream and gold halter dress and a fabulous peachy sheath that makes me want to shake my booty just thinking about it. I tried on both, the halter was an off label and only $30 and the peachy sheath w/ hand stitching was a label and $165; the owner/sales associate looked me over in them both and said the cream halter was a better fit from my skin tone and body build and would be more versatile and gently weened me away from the too snug sheath . That girl (what a cutie) saved me $130 and the embarrassment of looking like a mottled sausage or going on that diet. Because I paid with cash, she even gave me a discount. Seriously. As for price, Dovetail is the most fairly priced vintage I've encountered in Chicago. Somehow non serious vintage shoppers have gotten it into their heads that vintage should always mean cheap and it's my belief (handed down from my grandmother and great aunts) that if you want cheap old clothes then you can head to the resale shops or Am Vets or the Salvation Army (all of which I do) and when you want quality vintage pieces that will anchor your wardrobe or be your statement piece for years to come, you pay for it. I have a vintage dress I bought five years ago at $185, it needs some work but I plan on wearing it on my wedding day. Vintage is about commitment not some cheap score (though it's nice when it happens). It's possible to find both a cheap score and a piece for years to come at Dovetail. For that I'm appreciative.

5.description: Awesome mid-century modern items!  Especially cocktail sets.  I bought a very cool set for my friend for her birthday & can't wait to give it to her!  Super friendly customer service too:-)

25.description: I totally dig this place. It's a vintage-lifestyle joint with totally reasonable prices. I love the vibe here and the selection of clothes, accessories and furnishings was really great and you can tell it was picked with great taste. I'll definitely be back when I'm in the neighborhood.

12.description: I adore Dovetail.  I found it through Yelp! one day when I was jonesing for some vintage goodness, and have returned many times, never disappointed.  Very low-pressure staff, which is key for a small store like this one.  Good rotation of merch, and they're great about advertising sales and promoting art shows/music shows.  I've found several now-signature pieces there and always get compliments.  Price point is also pretty darn reasonable for the quality and variety of clothes there.Ooh, and I also picked up a vintage "Chicago" LP for $3 which is currently framed and hanging in my living room.  Not bad, not bad.

21.description: Dovetail has one of the greatest vintage selection in Chicago.  Love this place!!!

16.description: Julie is just about the loveliest shop owner I've met in the vintage boutique world.  On my first (or maybe second?) visit I was just popping in to stay warm and kill time while waiting for the bus.  And she actually got her iphone and looked up the bus schedule for me so I knew how much time I had to look around!  Then I somehow cut my finger on my jacket pocket and she rushed me some first aid supplies from the back.  Seriously!  Yeah, I was the dream customer: just looking and bleeding all over the place.  But she was as gracious as ever.I love the the windows and general aesthetic of Dovetail.  It's a little more upscale and lady-like.  The collection is super edited and I think their sense of style, understanding of the product, and level of service completely justify a higher price point.  I was sort of annoyed by the one negative review (Sandy D.) because I feel like a lot of small-scale boutiques get screwed by folks like that.  Buyers remorse can bring out the worst in people.  Sounds like those ebay prices came from unknowing sellers - pure luck.  And somehow this woman wanted the shop owner to abandon industry standards and common store policies to oblige her.  I know it's a tough business to be in and our local shops need our support more than ever!

17.description: Dovetail would be a fabulous addition to any Chicago neighborhood but that stretch of Chicago Ave. is certainly overdue for a boutique of this caliber.  You can't help but wander in when you see its unique and quirky ever-changing window displays.  The space is lovely and the fare is even better.  Whether you are searching for women, men, jewelry, furniture, odd knickknacks, or one of a kind presents you will not be disappointed.  The owners have impeccable taste and their excitement and love for vintage pieces is evident.  Go!  Shop!

10.description: I really wanted to like this store.I've been exploring the neighborhood and checking out vintage stores. This one is really pretty, but I found almost nothing. Also, I walked in and said 'hi' and was pretty much ignored. I went to try a couple of things. Still ignored.Two girls were busy chit chatting at the store.Yeah maybe because I wasn't dressed up in hip vintage clothing, but in semi corporate boring clothes.Also, I could not find anything my size. I found 2 cute skirts but they were too small and kinda pricey (I'm a size 2).

11.description: My favorite go-to shop in the city for anything and everything vintage. Julie (the owner) has a fantastic selection of vintage/antique home, apparel, and accessories to choose from. I can't come into the shop without leaving with something. She is constantly bringing in new merchandise, and supports local artists and jewelry makers as well. My favorites are her funky chunky jewelry pieces. Every piece i've purchased has received loads of compliments whenever I wear it. A gem in noble square. Perfect for yourself or gifts for others. Visit and you won't be disappointed!

26.description: Dovetail has a small yet perfect selection of vintage goodies, including jewelry, handbags, home goods, and other course, clothes.  They have a pretty ample selection of both men's and women's stuff, which is nice, given that a lot of stores offer a t-shirt or two in their men's collection.  The wonderful thing is that I didn't see a single thing that was anywhere near overpriced--the sticker matched the quality of the products.  I went in around Halloween seeking a cigarette holder for my Audrey costume, and although they had just sold their last one, I ended up walking out with the perfect wool winter skirt for like, 36 bucks.  Oh, and there is an adorable kitty hanging out from time to time, who is incredibly friendly.  I'm going back next week to do some holiday shopping, and I'm looking forward to finding some beautiful, unique pieces for some lovely friends and family.  For the not so lovely ones, I'm headed to Target.

27.description: Sorry, I haven't done a good yelp for a long while and have a lot of backed up reviews to do, plus it's 2:00 am in the morning and I'm watching To Catch a Predator, and am pretty bored and in a lot of pain, foot problems, so I decided to do some long over do reviews, first of which is Chicago's new vintage shop, Dovetail Chicago.    After, trying to figure out the hours of this freaking place, it was tricky and it's Wed thru Sun 12pm-8pm, I believe, I walked in and was cheered up and smiled at the pretty and avant backdrop of Dovetail. Dovetail's interior is mostly white giving it a hip, mod feel but with the warmness of the past with it's vintage goodies and array of vintage radios and furniture.      As the far as the merchandise goes, I was hoping for some more goodies, but that's the thing about vintage, some days are fulled with great things, other days are not. Not saying they didn't have nice things there, just some things were not for me. I did spot a few things I really liked: A hip looking travel bag that was in top shape, vintage eyewear, and a beautiful vintage pink, gold, and lavender dress that I fell in love with, it's plus-sized too, yes!!! It's probably the best looking plus-sized vintage dress I've ever seen, I either can't find decent plus-sized vintage clothes or if I do, they look very ugly. That reason alone is enough to keep me flying away to Dovetail!!

0.description: I bought a shirt here for a friend.  They have clothes for guys and gals, so they have their bases covered.  I needed a little help picking out a shirt for a girl, and they helped me find something that I wouldn't have originally picked.  As it turns out, I don't know what it takes because my friend loved it.Their guys clothes seemed cool.  They had shirts, ties,  and jackets, but what really caught my eye were the vintage hood ornaments.  I didn't see the price, which is probably good because I would have bought one.  They also have some vintage furniture for sale.Check out the tin ceiling.

20.description: Love this place. I'm actually not a hipster nor do I pretend to know anything about vintage clothing--but this place is superb for adding a little funk to your simple wardrobe. I tend to wear solids and accessorize--and this is a great place for that. I recently purchased a navy top with a very cool horizontal hem on the bottom. The sales woman--who I think is also the owner--knew what she was talking about and explained how this shirt would look with jeans or a pencil skirt. I also purchased a camel colored bubble skirt (from a local designer) and a red belt to match. I threw on a plain white tank, as was suggested by the owner, and received many compliments. Can't wait to go back!

19.description: When i first saw the jewelry designed by Julie Ghatan of  'Clank' at DEPART-ment a few years ago, i thought that it was going to be a hit.  and now, julie has opened 'dovetail chicago' that sweet little store on Chicago avenue just east of Ashland.  Julie and her partner, Jennifer have done a lovely job of collecting vintage designer goods and showcasing their own and local artists work.  It is worth the trip to see what they have done with the space!

2.description: I will concur. I first saw the Dovetails gals (and their wonderful vintage wares) at a trunk show at the May 2009 Yelp Retro Spring Fling...and it only took me about 18 months to FINALLY stop in for some vintage retail therapy on a blustery Sunday evening recently. Delayed buzz marketing at its finest, I say. Dovetail is top-notch when it comes to carefully culled vintage clothing, jewelry and accessories. It's absolutely a bit more high end than Seek a few doors down (also love), so this is more for...everyday wear and for selecting a few pieces to build around.  Think beautiful sweaters, skirts, dresses, etc. You won't necessarily find kitschy dresses you could wear to a throwback formal, costume-y jewelry or anything like that. You might, but it'll probably be a bit pricey if you just plan to wear it one evening. You WILL find classic pieces that have stood the test of time and look radiant even 40 years past their original heyday. My final purchase? A fantastically preserved purple "housecoat" that twirls just right as I pretend that I'm wearing it as a "housecoat" and not just as a dress over leggings. The bright orange detail punctuates the retro scale, and I can guarantee no one else in Chicago has this same piece. For $60, it was a deal. I've already worn it 4x, and I'm calling it my Thanksgiving outfit. There is a small dressing room...and the store is decorated in a fashion that makes you want to hike up those 'hose, slip on some white gloves and a housecoat and drink Manhattans while dreaming of men that look like Don Draper.
