35.description: It is impossible to find a better and more authentic Italian American grocery store sandwich than the kind served at Bari.  They also have a nice small butcher section,  though the meat isn't locally sourced.  I've gotten sandwiches here dozens of times.  Pure Chicago.

19.description: Oh Bari, how do you do it?! Consistently great subs. I've had the classic italian, meatball, and prosciutto and mozzarella -all fantastic. Unlike some other places, I know I can count on what they deliver hitting the spot with little to no customization. They serve up flavorful meats and cheeses, and I've never had any complaints over the bread (though I tend to like my sammies on a chewier roll). My boyfriend and I almost always get a sub for now and one for later. A+ for service. We ordered two 3 footers for a Super Bowl party to be picked up just before they closed that day (I believe around 4 pm). By 11:30 that morning, the snow was laying it on thick. We called to see if it was possible to move up pick up so we could get over there and get back before the roads were too nasty. We had the delicious subs in the car, slipping and sliding back home in less than an hour.The parking hunt can be annoying, but that's really the flavor of the neighborhood.

28.description: The Italian sub from Bari may be the best I've ever had! Bari is definitely my preferred sandwich joint in the area! The prosciutto and mozzarella sub was also very tasty! Will definitely be offering from Bari again!!

45.description: What a great old school Italian grocery store. Bari has delicious subs that are large in size and affordable. This almost reminds me of a place where Tony Soprano would come for some great gabagool. I usually either get the 12 inch Italian or Meatball sub. One thing to note is their bread is flaky and a little tougher than your normal soft sub bread. I prefer it this way, but I can see how some people would not like the texture if they are used to soft bread. One word of advice is to call-in ahead of time to place your order. If you go on the weekends you could be waiting in line for 20 minutes or more compared to walking in and getting your sub right away. I haven't purchased too many grocery items since the subs are so delicious, but I will soon. Oh yeah and they deliver too! I want to go pick a sub now! Keep up the prices and the quality Bari!

33.description: Bari is a neighborhood grocery that has managed to charm a large number or Chicago citizens over time. Everybody was talking about this place and especially about its sandwiches, so I decided it was time to find out whether Bari was worth all the positive comments. Once I entered this Italian style grocery store I noticed that customers were treated very nicely and more than 10 people were standing in line to buy sandwiches. I was pleased to see that this place sells a wide range of meat, hard bread and many other ingredients. The homemade giardiniera looked amazing so I couldn't help buying a jar, decision I totally praise now.  I also bought a prosciutto and mozzarella sandwich that made me fall in love with this place. I ate half of it and although I was already full I couldn't stop eating: that has seldom happened to me, as I am not very easy to please when it comes to food. I've been to Bari many times and I've had the chance to try all the products in this grocery. My favorite type of meat is the Barese sausage, which I buy whenever I happen to be in that area. Now I know why everybody was so pleased about this little Italian grocery called Bari, and I have even become one of its fans. No other place in Chicago has better sandwiches and sausages!

43.description: BIG fan of the italian beef and their italian sandwich on Focaccia bread! Large subs are VERY generous and prices can't be beat for the type of quality you're getting. The beef is not too thin and is delicious. Their homemade giardiniera pairs very well with the beef. The times i have gotten the beef I didnt request for a dip...i drive about 30 minutes to get home and by that time the bread has soaked up the juices so there's no need! The focaccia is great as well. Meats are fresh. Friendly service.TIP: hold your ground at the deli counter...people will cut...but karma will get them if so....

2.description: This place is about as Chicago Italian as they come and they have some great stuff inside. On this visit during X-Mas week, we came for sandwiches. Wonderful, wonderful Bari sandwiches. I cannot get Italian beef sandwiches in LA, where I have lived since 2002, and so that it is what I ordered... excellent. I also bought some of their house-made giardiniera for my suitcase. I haven't tried it yet, but it looks amazing. An excellent neighborhood deli.

18.description: In my opinion, Bari unequivocally makes the best "Italian" sub in the city.  I've been coming here for years, and even though they may not know my real name, they call me "Chuck Norris" ( guess they think I look like the old boy ! ! ) Although making a sub sandwich isn't rocket science, a noteworthy version can only be the sum of the freshest and best quality ingredients.  My checklist would include the following.  The bread should have a thin, crispy crust and soft crumb.  The meats & cheeses , lettuce & tomato must be both flavorful and freshly sliced.  And last, but not least, the giardiniera needs just the right amount of crunchy & soft veggies, herbs, and olive oil.  Bari meets all these standards. ( In addition, Bari makes its own giardiniera, and sells it in jars too)   Its no wonder the small place is always packed with customers.  Service is always prompt, but at prime time, you might need to wait a few minutes.  Its a small  price to pay for a terrific sub.  From Chicago cops and office workers to Italians from Harlem/Belmont, Brideport, or Elmwood Park, Bari is what the Italian-American sub is all about. If you happen to be looking for Italian groceries, they carry an ample selection of oils, canned tomato products,pasta, canned fish, and homemade condiments.  They also have fresh meats , homemade sausages, cheeses , and a wide selection of deli meats/salads.  If you don't enjoy cooking, checkout their prepared pastas and sauces.  (Currently, there are a few parking spaces just 2-3 doors South which are for customers shopping at Bari)

41.description: A true jewel in the city. Those three types of Italian sausage they gave us were the best sausages we have ever had. Also I have a list of the top three brands of anchovies in my wallet and have been looking for one of them here in Chicago for over a year. Finally found one at Bari's. Also the veal baloney just melts in your mouth. This is going to be a regular stop for us from now on!

52.description: OMG. I think I just found my favorite Italian beef in Chicago!!! I've tried it at Al's #1 in Wrigleville and different italian/pizzerias like Armands and Pizanos's in Wicker park to name a few. The flavor and quality of the meat is of most importance to me. Au juice and peppers are second. I find it a challenge to find a place where the beef is of good quality, flavorful, and is not too oily. Al's was way too oily and not flavorful at all. Why have all that oil if there's no flavor! lol. Others either had the beef too bland or chewy b/c it was overcooked. I got mild gardinera, pickles, and sweet peppers on mine. The au juice and combination of flavors were just right! Not too salty and did not leave an overwhelming after taste. I'm pretty sensitive to salty and processed foods so this was a pleasant surprise. Highly recommend it!!

50.description: For someone who doesn't care for for giardinara, I loved Bari's, and am now converted.  I tried both the hot and mild versions on their signature Italian sub, and it brought out tremendous flavor in the meat and spices.  The reason that I'm not giving a higher rating is because I ordered 3 subs, and the bread was crusty and didn't seem fresh.  I ordered Friday night before they closed and wonder if they were using up old bread.  Perhaps this wouldn't matter as much in the Italian beef sandwich, and I do plan on returning to try it at some point.

4.description: For a neighborhood grocer/deli, they sure do a brisk business around the lunch hour! Although it was a great spot to pick up some grub after a morning at the Shedd, parking was pretty non-existent and we had to park 3 blocks away!  Oh well, we had meatballs on the brain so we had to commit. When facing the deli counter, you order at the L side--the line kind of queues that way, there is no number system so just ask the person in front of you if they are in 'the line'. I've had the regular Italian sub here and was less than impressed.  There was just something about the bread that seemed "off".  Please don't tell me that you served me day old bread, it didn't seem as fresh as I thought Italian bread should be.  The meat?  excellent.  We went back to try the hot subs and shared the sausage sub and a meatball sub. Now I felt those were much better than the cold sub. The bread on both sandwiches was so much better. Fresh and chewy soft.  Both the meatball and sausage were flavorful, but I really liked the sausage more--the flavor was bolder and heartier. There are tons of different chips to round out your meal, a cooler of their house made sauces (yum!), cheeses, staples like pasta and olive oils, small selection of fresh veggies..lots of items packed in the small store.  Deli guys are abrupt, but the cashier ladies are always kind and chatty.  I love how they dote on my son.

6.description: BIG fan of the italian beef and their italian sandwich on Focaccia bread! Large subs are VERY generous and prices can't be beat for the type of quality you're getting. The beef is not too thin and is delicious. Their homemade giardiniera pairs very well with the beef. The times i have gotten the beef I didnt request for a dip...i drive about 30 minutes to get home and by that time the bread has soaked up the juices so there's no need! The focaccia is great as well. Meats are fresh. Friendly service.TIP: hold your ground at the deli counter...people will cut...but karma will get them if so....

22.description: For a neighborhood grocer/deli, they sure do a brisk business around the lunch hour! Although it was a great spot to pick up some grub after a morning at the Shedd, parking was pretty non-existent and we had to park 3 blocks away!  Oh well, we had meatballs on the brain so we had to commit. When facing the deli counter, you order at the L side--the line kind of queues that way, there is no number system so just ask the person in front of you if they are in 'the line'. I've had the regular Italian sub here and was less than impressed.  There was just something about the bread that seemed "off".  Please don't tell me that you served me day old bread, it didn't seem as fresh as I thought Italian bread should be.  The meat?  excellent.  We went back to try the hot subs and shared the sausage sub and a meatball sub. Now I felt those were much better than the cold sub. The bread on both sandwiches was so much better. Fresh and chewy soft.  Both the meatball and sausage were flavorful, but I really liked the sausage more--the flavor was bolder and heartier. There are tons of different chips to round out your meal, a cooler of their house made sauces (yum!), cheeses, staples like pasta and olive oils, small selection of fresh veggies..lots of items packed in the small store.  Deli guys are abrupt, but the cashier ladies are always kind and chatty.  I love how they dote on my son.

15.description: Great food, great price, great delivery! They don't really pay attention to the notes when ordering from eat24, but the sandwiches are good as is. Will definitely keep ordering, just may have to call in the special requests such as sides of dressing, or other extra condiments.

57.description: The subs scream out value for moneyTrumps the sub chains anyday..  They are heavy on spice seasonings .. Might ask them to go easy next time.. Most of their Grocery are on the expensive side.. They will survive just as a sandwich shop though

20.description: Best meatball sandwich available! Love the pre-prepared spaghetti & meatballs too!  The Bari hot sausage is the best Italian sausage I've ever eaten!

36.description: Best Italian sandwich in Chicago. And extremely reasonable price

14.description: Best Spicy Italian sub in Chicago.The extra spicy giardiniera is really spicy and really good.The pepper jack cheese actually has a pepper jack taste.You taste every part of the sandwich in every bite.So good.

3.description: What can I say about Tamikca???  She is not only a very talented stylist but her personality literally comes to life as soon as she laughs.  She has been my stylist through a few hair phases and all of them have been without a relaxer. I love that there is a stylist that can do my hair and it is not too far from home.  I would recommend her to any man or woman with any texture of hair.  She will work with you honestly and make you look and feel fabulous.Tamikca Rocks!!!!

1.description: The best hair stylist hands down, that cares about your hair!

2.description: Tamikca is fantastic!!..awesome personality and great attention to detail. Extremely talented and makes sure she does styles(up dos) that lasts if needed...Books enough time per client, so no one has to wait!!..Don't hesitate to book her.

5.description: I'm giving you one star because I've called 3 times since 4/30 and I haven't received a call back. And I'm supposed to call you for a consultation before I make an appointment for minitwists or senegalese twists. It's really too bad because you're one of the few black stylists in the area and you could do really well. Not sure how else I can get a hold of you. I guess you don't want my money?

6.description: What can I say but she's THE BEST. Natural hair is her specialty but she is very diverse and has experience styling many hair types and styles. I've been going to Tamikca for around 2 years and my hair has never been healthier.  I've been trying to get back the length I had when I was young (middle back) and this is the closest I've been in years.  She gives real and excellent advice, even if it could impact her $$.  She's awesome!

7.description: I was honestly too nervous to write a review for Tamikca before because I didn't want her to get so incredibly busy that I would not be able to get in to see her again! However, I am in a generous mood and it is only fair that I give her the long overdue praise that she deserves. I went to Tamicka because I was interested in transitioning from a relaxer to my natural hair without chopping it all off and starting over. All I can say is that it is beyond wonderful to have a stylist who knows so much about how to care for African-American hair. She patiently guided me through the "transition" process and helped me to keep my hair healthy throughout. When I first came to Tamicka my hair was chin length, dry and damaged. I now have a shiny, healthy, chemical-free hair that is inches past my shoulder--all this was accomplished with Tamikca's guidance and know-how. Also, GONE are the days when I spend hours in the salon because they're busy and overbooked. With Tamikca, your time is YOURS from start to finish. I love the fact that I have NEVER waited for her to get started with me in the years I have been working with her. She's really the best in the business and I highly recommend her for anyone who wants a stylist who cares about your hair as much, if not more, than you.

0.description: Tamikca is the bomb.com PERIOD. She always takes her time, styling and pampering my natural tresses to perfection. My hair is the longest and STRONGEST its ever been under her tender love and care. It's so difficult to find a great stylist that knows natural hair inside and out (minimal heat, using tons of moisturizing products and patience).. I finally found this in Tamikca.Btw, Tamikca also gave me a fabulous multi dimensional color (mix of deep brown, caramel and warm blonde highlights) that I receive complements on all the time! Don't hesitate to book your appointment. You won't be disappointed! :-)

4.description: She's the most fun ever, for one. Also, she wasn't afraid to tackle my natural hair, and gave me the best haircut I've ever had... While it was wet *gasp*. The style was AWESOME. It took a while, with the hair cut, and then having to twist and roll it (I got a roller set), then having to sit under the dryer. It was, in total, a 6 hour process. But it was WELL worth it. A bit pricey, so I won't be able to go a often as I might like, but she gave me so many tips that I don't feel obligated to go all the time (though I will be seeing her at least every 3-4 months, I'm not allowing anyone else to cut my hair, ever). Since I've met her I've been trying to get everyone to make an appointment, that's how fantastic she was. Can't wait to get back!

attributes.Hair Types Specialized In: African-American Hair, Asian Hair, Curly Hair, Extensions, Coloring

28.description: I'm a regular at this thrift store for over a year now. This is probably the most pricey thrift store I've been in but its the biggest. I found my high top dinning table there for $150. It sells for $399 at target and its just like new. They have a huge furniture section downstairs and if you wait it out the stuff that's been there for a month goes on sale. They have a great "antique" section where I purchase my 1950's Westinghouse alarm clock for $35.00 which sells for $75 in a worse condition than mine. I found a slightly used Wii guitar hero set for $60! Its been working great for over a year now.  So I've been very happy with my purchases! There are three levels of goodness in this thrift store and make sure to dig!

1.description: I've been actively visiting thrift stores in the city of Chicago and Chicagoland.  This one is located east from the CTA Grand Blue line station.  Once you get out of the subway station, figure out which one is Grand Ave. and walk east for two (2) minutes, you will see it.  If you're moving and in need of furniture, I think it may have something in store for you.  The first floor primarily features sofas, mirrors, tables, desks, and other miscellaneous living-room and dining-room essentials.  The prices I saw are more than reasonable.  You can get a college dormitory style futon for under $50.  I should have known better where to get my futon when I was in college, but I didn't know the world that well at that time.  What a dismay!  The second floor contains all clothing, accessories, and footwear items.  I don't recommend to shop for clothing in a Salvation Army thrift store, for they tend to mark their prices higher on apparel than what a Village Discount Outlet would.  Nevertheless, if you're desperate for shoes, often times shoes found in a Salvation Army are cleaner and in a more pristine condition.  That's just an observation, but what you can find really depends on each individual Salvation Army Thrift Store.  The quality of neighborhood where the store is located also matters.  The basement resembles an old man's workshop.  You can find utility items, bikes, random gadgets, and someone's DePaul University Juris Doctor diploma...back in the 60's.  With that being said, the air isn't going to be ventilating well.  The candles they are selling are probably the only substances to make the air smell a little bit endurable.  Sounds like an awesome, adventurous store, so why three (3) stars?  Hubby was confused with how much a vinyl record costs.  I told him that he might have to ask a manager for pricing or to make a deal or something.  At the same time, I didn't think he found anything that he wanted to purchase.  Does anyone who has purchased vinyl records in a Salvation Army thrift store know what much each piece cost?  Let me know.

9.description: I am a thrift-store junkie. Live and die by Goodwill, Value Village, and everything in between. My mom shudders when she thinks that the vast majority of my clothes still come from a thrift store, and I am well past college and "needing" to shop at thrift stores.Oh but I NEED to shop at thrift stores because it gives me purpose and meaning and that little flutter of joy when you find a treasure. And I will ALWAYS come out of a thrift store with at least 3 or 4 things. Sadly, my love doesn't extend to this Salvation Army, as I walked out dejected and empty handed. Since it is so large, I thought there would be tons of great finds, but I was sad to only see overpriced...CRAP. Literally, broken, falling apart, crap. Sigh. I imagined it's proximity to River North would mean a mecca of cast-offs and hidden gems. Maybe I hit it on an off-day, but my first Chicago thrift trip was an utter failure.

29.description: I had previously thought Village Discount near Logan Square was the best thrift store in town, but now I believe it to be the Salvation Army by the train tracks. It appears a desolate and rather shoddy location, but the inside, in contrast to other area thrift stores, is clean, spacious, devoid of crowds on a Friday afternoon and FULL of nice things. You would even think at times that you were in a vintage boutique of hand-picked items. It does seem a bit "pricier" than Village Discount, as in a shirt might cost $3 instead of $1.79...but I can live with that.

23.description: I am a thrift-store junkie. Live and die by Goodwill, Value Village, and everything in between. My mom shudders when she thinks that the vast majority of my clothes still come from a thrift store, and I am well past college and "needing" to shop at thrift stores.Oh but I NEED to shop at thrift stores because it gives me purpose and meaning and that little flutter of joy when you find a treasure. And I will ALWAYS come out of a thrift store with at least 3 or 4 things. Sadly, my love doesn't extend to this Salvation Army, as I walked out dejected and empty handed. Since it is so large, I thought there would be tons of great finds, but I was sad to only see overpriced...CRAP. Literally, broken, falling apart, crap. Sigh. I imagined it's proximity to River North would mean a mecca of cast-offs and hidden gems. Maybe I hit it on an off-day, but my first Chicago thrift trip was an utter failure.

5.description: Spent two hours in the Sally Army on Saturday - unlike Goodwill and other thrift outlets, the clothes are sorted by color, not sizes, so you have to root around a little to find what fits. I snagged a spanking-new, never-worn Banana Republic blazer for less than $8 and a couple of really nice dress shirts for $3.50. Downstairs, there were dozens of sets of golf clubs, and "bric a brac" galore - glassware, artwork, toys, dishes, Tupperware, travel mugs...you name it. The whole place is a bit musty and moldy, so if you have allergies, you might wanna pop a couple Sudafed before heading in. The wife had a bit of a sneezing fit after 90 minutes, and my eyes were burning by the time we left. The furniture prices see a smattering high, but there were some nice deals on futons and end tables. Go play. Have fun!

31.description: YES THIS PLACE IS WAAAAAAAAY OVERPRICED BUT.....I have found some killer finds.I purchased a few black and white vintage photos that were AMAZING and a john wayne display piece for the release of the movies to vhs.... i got a kick out of that.The furniture and most of the antiques are laughable because of the prices. The staff is rude... but if you look past that they have some amazing things and with everything thats over priced you can walk out after having a good laugh!

25.description: Awful! We've been in the market for a sofa and loveseat so I'm familiar with the ranges of quality and price and I can't believe what a rip off this place is! You could easily get a better deal at some department stores! Sofas that most likely cost $350 brand new were about $320 from this place, and if you can afford that, who wants to buy a couch from a thrift shop when they can spend an extra $30 to have it brand new! They had some pretty cool antiques and mirrors that we ran into but, go figure, they were extremely overpriced as well. Disappointing.

12.description: I would have gone straight to the 4 star review, but they must have an in-house appraiser because their antique stuff is very on the money, which means not cheap for me.They do have an antique floor- the staff is mostly inadequate, in that, most people working there don't really know anything and really don't want to help.For example- tacky 70s lamp table with cabinet attached, not bad condition- missing shade- 30 dollars? WTF. Really, seriously? This was laminate. LAMINATE. However, they are one of the only few places to fuel my salt n pepper collectibles issue.I always stop, but I don't have expectations and I know not to spend the money if I think the price is too high, as it probably is.

37.description: Biggest shop in town. They have a whole floor of furniture, so come here if that's what you're looking for. Some is very nice, but is priced higher than I expected. This shop is three stories  - basement and second floor - second floor is all clothing.

21.description: This is the most expensive thrift store you could ever imagine. They do have a lot of stuff (some of it is even nice) but their prices are so high you can easily get the equivalent item in a regular store for a cheaper price.I stopped in today to look at bicycles and saw a sign saying "All bicycles - 50%."  That gave me a smile and got my hopes up.  I went to the bike area and found a dozen or two bikes ranging from kids' bikes to mountain bikes, to pleasure cruisers.  The bikes were in very poor condition -- picture a 35 year old bike that was left on the side of the road and hit by a garbage truck.  Next picture it covered in dust and with flat tires.  Next picture the price tag stuck to the seat that reads $250.00.All the bikes (even a pedal-less kids' bike) were priced at $100 or more.  The highest one I saw was $350.00 for a department store plain carbon steel (not even 4130 or aluminum) frame mountain bike.The person in charge of pricing at this store seems to be delusional.

16.description: The person who said "this place takes all the fun out of thrifting" is right. This place is terrible. They sell mostly junk, and anything that has a decent brand label usually has a major flaw (check for tears in the crotch and around the pockets in jeans).  It's absolutely worth your while to travel to a different store. Spending any time here will disappoint you, and if your experience doesn't bring you down, the nasty salespeople will. Don't waste your time.

17.description: As an avid thrifter i don't like to give away my secrets but I am so pissed that I have to complain! I went on a sat and it was empty- that alone should have been my first clue! No thrift store is empty on a saturday! Three floors of stuff, the first is furniture ok quality but high priced. $150-$300 for a couch. The staff let me walk around for 20 mins then four different employees demanded I hand over my bag. Earlier posters mentioned racism but im a white gal and there Hispanic ladies that came in at the same time. we were all accosted. The staff were also rude as hell, instead of saying excuse me to get through isles staff stared you down and said: "Really?" but thats fine, thrift stores aren't known to be the most selective of employers. It's the prices that got me! Used generic shoes for $17-45! I'm not kidding, I took a picture to prove this bullshit. Anything of value is marked way the fuck up and everything else is cheap. Even banana republic stuff would be cheaper on eBay. Don't waste your time - even as close as this is to the blue line it's not worth it. You might find vintage clothing reasonably priced but most anything else marked the f- up!

10.description: I was surprised to see all the bad reviews.  I've been going to this shop for over a decade and continue to find great things at amazing prices.First the bad.-They do have alot of surplus from Target marked at too-expensive prices-They do price their Coats, furniture, vintage and collectible times more like an antique store than a resale shop.-The staff, some of which have been there for many years is not well trained in customer service and you do have to check your bags at the front, something they don't always request in the kindest of tones.The good:If you're willing to dig, and aren't turned off by finding some items priced too high, you can find great prices on lots of items including clothes as well as housewares and toys (Second story and Basement respectively) I routinely find top brand clothes in good shape for 3-6 dollars an item.  Just today I was wearing a GAP Cardigan from SA that cost me 3 bucks.  Sometimes you'll go and not find anything, but this store has been the source of some of my best and cheapest finds.   This shouldn't be your only thrift store (there are lots of other great stores in and around Chicago) but it's on my list and I stop by whenever I can.

11.description: I agree with Kyle K, this is definitely one of the most expensive thrift stores I've ever been to.  It's a very big store with 3 floors of overpriced items (for a SA store).  Lots of stuff was from Target and still had the Target price tags on, and some of the SA prices were the about the same as the Target prices!Keep your eyes open, the storefront is not very well marked, so blink and you'll miss it!  Street parking is easy.  Basement - housewares, brick a brack, etc. I noticed lots of brand new stuff from Target. Lots of other junk.Main floor - furniture.  Expensive furntiure.  There were two very nice vintage armchairs in the front that were $750 a piece!!!  The furniture from Target was about the same price as you'd pay at the actual store!  Books were nicely organized, but more expensive than other SAs.  Some were marked upwards of $5-6, usually they're no more than $2.50 for the big hardcover books.Second floor - Clothes and also a "vintage" area where everything was very expensive.  Clothes were also more expensive than other SAs and thrift stores. We spent 1 hour here and didn't buy a thing.  Will not be back.  Things are way too expensive here for a thrift store.  Rather go to Family Dollar or an actual Target store and buy something new rather than salvaged.

26.description: I honestly went here today to find a slinket for cheap. I'm too embarrassed to buy one at full price but think about getting one almost every other damn day. You would think with three floors, surely a slinket would be laying around SOMEwhere. I looked and looked but all my efforts were to no avail. And there was a lot to look at.This place is three floors huge. The first floor is mostly furniture, etc. Let me let you in on a little secret. For one reason or another, they have a lot of unopened Target merchandise on this floor. From frames to storage to memory foam, they've strangely got a whole lot of stuff from there. So if you're a big Target fan (like me), go nuts. Downstairs is their bric-a-brac area, mostly where old televisions and computer monitors come to die. So much useless junk for, in my opinion, too much money. The bottom floor looks like a burial site and it's mostly because no one is buying anything. If it were up to me, I'd put everything up for a dollar and just got rid of all that junk. But that's just me.Upstairs is clothes, mostly. I couldn't find anything I liked, but then again, I think I'm wayyy over the whole "dress in used clothes to look cool" movement. Too much stuff to look at and no AC so I said SEE YA pretty quick.Either way- not bad. I like places like this because it's like rummaging through a GIGANTIC garage sale- and who knows what you'll find? Just bring your patience along and skip the bottom floor for sure.

27.description: Egad, if you've got a ton of money that you might as well just donate it to the charity, instead of trying to pick through all the bric a brac here.  It's like walking through a museum, things are nicely organized and displayed but there is no way I'm going to spend that much $$$ on thrifted goodness.  I'm surprised this place makes any profit from the merchandise because the prices are so high, they elevate my blood pressure.  Now don't get me wrong, some of the stuff isn't total junk, but it's more then a sane person should be spending.  Shopping at a thrift store means being frugal, not getting ripped off.  Plus parking is a total pain in the ass in the area.   I like how there is a sign that says that they don't accept $50's and $100's but it's unlikely that you will find anything under that price point anyway.  What do they expect, you to carry a giant wad of $1 bills?  Real thrifters, I urge you to go elsewhere!

35.description: My daughter loves this place for vintage clothing, t-shirts and accessories.  We have been making this a regular stop for the past three years during our annual Chicago visits.  The furniture may not be a bargain, but the clothing is thrift store priced and there's lots of it.

8.description: The prices are ridic. They actually had Suave Shampoo marked for $4. Umm. Osco,Jewel, Target, everywhere sells it for 99 cents. They think they are Hermes. They aren't. Everything they have is near retail and you can't return it. Go to look, you may find a bargain but just because it is here, doesn't mean its cheap.

0.description: This is the closest donation site to my place, and yet this was the first time I went to this location. It is kind of tucked away off of Grand on Union and you have to go inside to drop off items through a door to your left once you are inside. There is no person that was there to collect my items or give me a receipt either. I had to wait in line where purchases were being made with the cashier filling out the form. This location has 3 levels of items where the main floor where you enter has furniture, upstairs has clothing, and downstairs has the extra stuff. The prices are somewhat reasonable, but the staff off Clybourn is much friendlier.

20.description: I agree with Kyle K, this is definitely one of the most expensive thrift stores I've ever been to.  It's a very big store with 3 floors of overpriced items (for a SA store).  Lots of stuff was from Target and still had the Target price tags on, and some of the SA prices were the about the same as the Target prices!Keep your eyes open, the storefront is not very well marked, so blink and you'll miss it!  Street parking is easy.  Basement - housewares, brick a brack, etc. I noticed lots of brand new stuff from Target. Lots of other junk.Main floor - furniture.  Expensive furntiure.  There were two very nice vintage armchairs in the front that were $750 a piece!!!  The furniture from Target was about the same price as you'd pay at the actual store!  Books were nicely organized, but more expensive than other SAs.  Some were marked upwards of $5-6, usually they're no more than $2.50 for the big hardcover books.Second floor - Clothes and also a "vintage" area where everything was very expensive.  Clothes were also more expensive than other SAs and thrift stores. We spent 1 hour here and didn't buy a thing.  Will not be back.  Things are way too expensive here for a thrift store.  Rather go to Family Dollar or an actual Target store and buy something new rather than salvaged.

19.description: I honestly went here today to find a slinket for cheap. I'm too embarrassed to buy one at full price but think about getting one almost every other damn day. You would think with three floors, surely a slinket would be laying around SOMEwhere. I looked and looked but all my efforts were to no avail. And there was a lot to look at.This place is three floors huge. The first floor is mostly furniture, etc. Let me let you in on a little secret. For one reason or another, they have a lot of unopened Target merchandise on this floor. From frames to storage to memory foam, they've strangely got a whole lot of stuff from there. So if you're a big Target fan (like me), go nuts. Downstairs is their bric-a-brac area, mostly where old televisions and computer monitors come to die. So much useless junk for, in my opinion, too much money. The bottom floor looks like a burial site and it's mostly because no one is buying anything. If it were up to me, I'd put everything up for a dollar and just got rid of all that junk. But that's just me.Upstairs is clothes, mostly. I couldn't find anything I liked, but then again, I think I'm wayyy over the whole "dress in used clothes to look cool" movement. Too much stuff to look at and no AC so I said SEE YA pretty quick.Either way- not bad. I like places like this because it's like rummaging through a GIGANTIC garage sale- and who knows what you'll find? Just bring your patience along and skip the bottom floor for sure.

33.description: If you don't like dingy thrift stores, don't come. End of story. This is the largest salvation army store in the country. It has three stories. The basement has a strange conglomeration of sports equipment, luggage, electronics, and kitchenwares. The first floor is furniture (which is actually pretty expensive, all things considered, but I have seen some very cool items in there), and a corner that does look like it's filled with random things donated from Target. Top floor is where I love to venture the most. They have a sort of antique section that is closed half the week, and it's incredibly fun browsing through the massive amounts of china, strange old gadgets, and antique coke brand products. The other half of the floor is clothes, most of which are crappy. The south and west walls are lines with coats. I've snagged several great blazers off their jacket rack. It's hopeless to look through the jeans. Perhaps the most fun I've had is in with some girlfriends and trying on the dresses in their back room dedicated to wedding and fancy dresses. It's unbelievable. Everything seems to be 70's and 80's and incredibly ugly, which makes it SO MUCH FUN and produces some awesome photos. It is dingy and dusty and if that sort of thing bugs you, skip it. If you're looking for a really cute outfit, skip it. If you're out for an adventure or you like exploring, this is certainly one place to try.

2.description: REVIEW ON 10/6/2014.  I never used to be much of a thrift store shopper.  Bloomies is more my speed.  But earlier this year, I hit the Goodwill in Moline, IL with my sister and walked out with a used $2,500 (retail) Fendi Spy Bag for $20.  Beginner's luck.  Obviously, no one behind the counter knew the brand Fendi.  Of course, that would probably never happen in Chicago, but I keep hoping I'll get lucky again.  Stopped in at this Salvation Army a few blocks from my place, and all I can say is... crazy.  Crazy prices, that is.  I can do better at Macy's with a good sale plus a coupon from the Trib.   The first floor is mainly furniture and a few accessories.  I looked at two mid-century chairs for $225 each, and both needed costly refinishing and reupholstering.  They wouldn't budge on the price.  Nothing attracted me on the top floor or in the basement except for a $24 teak salad bowl, too much for used. Lots of mix-matched kitchen stuff, used electronics, plus a few uninteresting antiques were of little interest.  This store is more picked over than a farmer's market just before closing.  I saw a few people buying things, but I left with nothing.  Thrift shopping is hit or miss.  You never know what you'll find.   Although I can't say anything positive about my experience here, several college-aged friends picking through the clothes were obviously very happy with their finds.  Someone had donated a lot of Banana Republic stuff with the tags still on them. My search will continue, because once you're bitten by the thrift store bug, it's hard to stop.  I'm posting a picture of my Fendi bag from the Moline Goodwill to inspire my fellow thrift store shopper.UPDATED REVIEW ON 8/20/2015:  Stopped in a week ago for the first time since my original review last year.  It's much improved.  Better organized, cleaner, and the prices were a little more reasonable.  The salesperson told me they have a new manager.  I picked up a mid-century ceramic vase for $20... about $15 less than I saw it on Etsy.  They still need to do better on the pricing, but I'm giving them an extra star for the improvements.

34.description: If I could give this store 0 stars I would! This place sucks! They are so overpriced it is ridiculous!   It's as if everything was donated from Target and they are charging the list price for the item. It's not even the good stuff from target. Just tacky purses and other junk. Don't waste your time, go to Village Discount Outlet.

32.description: Being a prop person for theater really helps when it comes to planning something like your own wedding.....I know where all the best deals are and what stores have what.  This is my favorite Salvation Army in the city.  I bought a bunch of different shaped glass vases here, none more than a dollar, and sprayed them all white for a mighty classy effect.The best part of this store is their basement.  Their furniture prices have gotten out of hand, far too expensive.  The third floor antique shop has some good stuff occasionally but their prices are a bit delusional sometimes too.Well wait, this was in conjunction with my wedding planning so I better not give away all my hard-fought theater tips for free here.  Point being, the basement has some great bargains on things that can help you decorate!

18.description: Minorities not wanted. My wife and I (both Asian) stumbled upon this place when walking on a date night. Entering into the cavernous cement-walled shop we passed by dust and mildew laden furniture that was basting under low-lit halogen bulbs. This Salvation Army is more of a collection of thrown out garbage than a place of well-cared for collectibles.Still as my wife and I were there, wondering if we could find any worthwhile surprises, we turned the first corner of the main room. That was when we heard the raspy voice. "Take off your bag and purse. You're going to have to give me your bag," the larynx-challenged voice said. My wife and I looked to see where the sound was coming from, and then looked at the small brown leather Calvin Klein bag that my wife was wearing. We walked a couple steps forward and heard the raspy entonement: "Take off your bag and purse and give them to me."As we had passed by some of the shoulder high clutter that was piled up in the center of the room, we saw the old employee who had gasped out the words, standing in front of the cash register table. My wife and I looked around to see whom the woman was talking to. From this vantage point a quick visual sweep of the room showed one other shopping husband and wife couple, a mother and daughter, and a single woman. The four female shoppers who'd preceded us into the store all wore larger bags on their backs or hips than the bag that my wife carried. My wife and I approached the clerk to clarify, and the clerk repeated the demand with a stare. Let me take a pause from this narrative to say that I'm not one to say the sky is falling, so this Salvation Army clerk's behavior was really annoying. By simply turning our necks left and right, my wife and I saw four women who had entered before us, sashaying down the aisles with bigger bags swaying in rhythm. I asked the clerk about the other patrons and if she was going to talk to them about their bigger bags. Her immediate response was (and I kid you not): "Yes, I'm White. I'm going to talk to them, too. I just haven't had a chance to get to them yet." Allow me to point out that I'd asked her about the other customers' larger bags and what the clerk planned to do, yet the employee's  first response was that she's White. Then there's the fact that the other customers had been walking around for minutes before us.  Stupid is as stupid does.In embarrassment by the blatant racism, the single female shopper who was standing by the register ready to check out, swung her purse from back to front to show how much bigger her purse was than my wife's bag. My wife began taking out our wallets and phones, while the clerk repeated her self admission. Given the store's treatment, "offerings", and the spoiling of an until then perfect date night, I asked my wife to repack her bag as I didn't want to stay in the shop any longer. Its incredible that in this day and age, in a large metropolitan city such Chicago, racism still exists. Thank goodness for Yelp, which enabled me to not only find and confirm other Yelpers' reviews about the racism at this Salvation Army, but also to reiterate that the shop and its items are dreadful.

13.description: PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE don't go there. Save your time, your money, your feet and everything that can constitute an opportunity cost. I read some of the reviews here ( which were pretty bad) but as a queen of thrift shopping , I decided to go anyway.Needless to say, that I was mad at myself for not listening. I was just digusted with this place. As soon as I opened the door , the lady yelled at me to give her my bag ( I'm black but I'm not a thief-sorry) . Nothing special there, the place is just ugly, with items that range from $10 to $100000000000. Yeah, that's how expensive it is.  And also, I was looking at the bags and this other person came at me and said "are you ready to pay?"  I was really shocked and then when she looked at my face , she tried to apologize. I've seen this one beautiful jacket that I ended up buying but other than that, nothing really to be excited about.So please, again save your time and money and don't step into this horrible place.

4.description: Not sure I agree with the consensus on this one. This place rules! It's massive with tons of everything from clothes to furniture to props to other random stuff and you get it all for super cheap. They keep it pretty organized considering how big it is and how few employees they have. It's the perfect place to go for themed parties, Halloween, or just to kill some time before getting a table at La Scarola across the street. Sure...It's a thrift store so of course it's going to smell like moth balls and you'll have to do some digging for the good stuff but that's part of the fun of it anyways.

24.description: This is a gigantic store. One star for hugeness. I didn't make it down into the basement, just the clothes on the third floor and a walk through the furniture on the ground floor. Clothes seemed to be decently priced, and if you're a size 6 or under I totally recommend shopping here. If you tend towards the curvier, though, they don't have that much. The furniture I looked at was definitely overpriced. A used particle-board and veneer dresser for $125? Really? It was dreadfully hot inside, too, and it wasn't even THAT hot of a day. I'd hate to be there in the dead of summer. I wound up walking out without buying anything. This was just as well, since I walked around to corner to where my car was parked (on Ohio) to find that someone had smashed my driver's side window. I'll need that money I didn't spend in order to get it replaced. People driving buy who live in the neighborhood clucked sympathetically and and said "Happens all the time on this street." So yeah; park at the meters on Union or over on Grand. Stay away from the free parking on Ohio, though. Ugh.

6.description: Ok, I agree with the other reviews now. The prices are nuts. I can't even fathom how much they charge for some of these clothes. Jeans with a big hole right in the butt $8. Half empty bottle of Suave shampoo $4. I don't even get it. Avoid if you can.

22.description: I went to this location to stock up on items after moving cross country. Much of my great stuff in Cali went to them before I moved.I was hoping to find a dish set and a few other items. Not only was all the bric-a-brac crappy ... but it was overpriced for the SA. I broke down and bought what looked like a new small rug for $10 ... I know it would cost more elsewhere, but felt it was overpriced in any case.They did have some nice looking furniture, but again, looked overpriced. Whomever is doing their pricing is having a field day, for sure. Maybe it's because it's kind of adjacent to the downtown area near northish ... they figure they can gauge the downtowners who don't know any better.I have since gone to many other SAs in the region and they were all much better than this one, where I have found linens, coats and other stuff.I have found that the further out I go, the lower the prices are. Makes sense. It was worth the train ride out to the store off Sheridan. Killer!I won't be back to this one soon, however.

15.description: This is the most expensive thrift store you could ever imagine. They do have a lot of stuff (some of it is even nice) but their prices are so high you can easily get the equivalent item in a regular store for a cheaper price.I stopped in today to look at bicycles and saw a sign saying "All bicycles - 50%."  That gave me a smile and got my hopes up.  I went to the bike area and found a dozen or two bikes ranging from kids' bikes to mountain bikes, to pleasure cruisers.  The bikes were in very poor condition -- picture a 35 year old bike that was left on the side of the road and hit by a garbage truck.  Next picture it covered in dust and with flat tires.  Next picture the price tag stuck to the seat that reads $250.00.All the bikes (even a pedal-less kids' bike) were priced at $100 or more.  The highest one I saw was $350.00 for a department store plain carbon steel (not even 4130 or aluminum) frame mountain bike.The person in charge of pricing at this store seems to be delusional.

7.description: Salvation Army will never get another donation from us-  there are so many charities that care and want donations-  if you give to Salvation Army your donations will be treated worse than a garbage dump-  don't believe me?  Take a drive to Waukeagan and watch your stuff get "donated" - ha-  dumped on a heap of other donations - probably never to get to people who truly need it-

36.description: I totally agree with the below post-- It is completely lame how they charge retail prices for things they receive for free... And I don't understand the rational for charging what they do... Lower class cannot afford their furniture... If the sold it for less I believe they would turn a quick profit, instead I think there banking on charging retail and hoping people see their purchase as a donation-- boo! Also a side note--- I had to do community service at a Salvation army (won't go into details about why) -- but anything especially good that comes in goes directly into the employee that saw it first car. ( Not that this is still happening- but at the location I was at for numerous hours weekend-weekend that's how it went down!) so consider it-

30.description: As others have said their furniture is quite overpriced.  For example; I found an Aneboda wardrobe that sells at Ikea for around $100 that was mark $150 a while ago.  If you search through the clothes or the downstairs area you may find some decent finds though.  Its worth a shot if you are in the area but not worth traveling there for.

3.description: Wow, 2 weeks in a row I waited from 8am till 4pm to donate a sofa and no one showed up. Both times I had confirmation calls. After the first day of a no show I was supposed to be the first on the list the following week but instead I received a call at 3:18pm they just weren't coming. Please don't waste your time donating to The Salvation Army in Chicago because they couldn't careless about it.

14.description: I went to this location to stock up on items after moving cross country. Much of my great stuff in Cali went to them before I moved.I was hoping to find a dish set and a few other items. Not only was all the bric-a-brac crappy ... but it was overpriced for the SA. I broke down and bought what looked like a new small rug for $10 ... I know it would cost more elsewhere, but felt it was overpriced in any case.They did have some nice looking furniture, but again, looked overpriced. Whomever is doing their pricing is having a field day, for sure. Maybe it's because it's kind of adjacent to the downtown area near northish ... they figure they can gauge the downtowners who don't know any better.I have since gone to many other SAs in the region and they were all much better than this one, where I have found linens, coats and other stuff.I have found that the further out I go, the lower the prices are. Makes sense. It was worth the train ride out to the store off Sheridan. Killer!I won't be back to this one soon, however.

58.description: I work for a charity in Chicago called Rock For Kids (rockforkids.org) which provides free year-round music lessons to children living under the poverty level.For years, April 7s has been one of the three main framers that we use every year to frame items in our Annual Rock & Roll Auction. Every year we have nearly 200 items signed by bands and other celebrities, and most of those items need framed.Martin and Julie at April 7s are so helpful and are creative geniuses. We basically drop off the items and 95% of the time ask them to just do something cool. However, when we have our own bright ideas they are very thoughtful and accommodating, offering us their advice. They never disappoint! Their hand cut mats are particularly spectacular. One year they created an amazing boom box frame for a signed Beastie Boys microphone, and another year they created a light box to backlight a Tom Waits poster.  People who come to our auction always want to know who frames our stuff!I love April 7s so much I've even had them frame a number of personal items for my apartment and for gifts.To see samples of the stunning framing that April 7s have done for Rock For Kids visit the following link:flickr.com/photos/rockfo…Thank you April 7s for all that you do for Rock For Kids!

56.description: I'm tickled pink by the quality and service at this small, locally-owned shop. Martin and his crew may not be the fastest game in town when it comes to framing, but I didn't mind the little bit of extra time the job took because they paid attention to all the little details. And they're just so gosh-darned nice! Definitely bringing all my custom stuff over here from now on.

29.description: I first found out about April 7s when I was interning and would go there to pick up framed prints for the person I was working for. Everyone was so nice, knowledgeable and helpful that when it came to framing some prints that i had purchased, it was a no brainer that I would go to April 7s. I had an idea of what I wanted, but I wasn't 100% sure. I worked with Evan and he helped me find exactly what I was looking for. I picked my frames up today, and they came out beautifully! I can't wait to hang them on my walls this weekend. I will definitely come back here again and suggest you come here too!

42.description: While searching for local framers, I figured I should write a review for April 7s seeing how they have framed two separate projects of my original work (this was back when they were on Chicago Ave). They did such an amazing job that their custom matting and framing not only enhanced, but added to and became a part of the finished piece.This time around I'm looking just to frame some posters and prints.  I highly suggest April 7s though if you ever need stellar customer service and a fun, but contemporary framing job.

23.description: I had three items recently framed here using a Yelp deal.  Friendly, knowledgeable, professional.... Also will suggest options based on your budget.  A wee bit expensive but then the quality of work is superb.

47.description: These guys have way more frame options in store than other places I've been to, and I had a great time picking out an awesome frame from the gentleman who helped me.Along the way, things happened and they lost the order slip, which is fine -- it's just that the slip says that I can't pick it up until the middle of May (even though I dropped in off some time in the end of March/beginning of April.  So props to their level of flexibility for letting me keep it there for that long).  However, I keep getting calls saying that my piece is ready to be picked up even though I leave them a voice mail every time they call saying that I'm a May pickup.  They don't seem to know about my messages and don't have email, so I'm dropping a star for the lack of information flow if you do have a problem but can't stop by the store.I'm sure the piece is lovely, though.  I'd just like for them to call me back telling me that they're received my voicemails.  I'm the bluegreen water and dock poster with a thick black textured frame.  I don't know what else to do but post this information here, honestly, hoping that they'll read it.

8.description: This store is amazing! They really walked me through the process and I am thrilled with the results. I had three things framed, each very different, and they are awesome. Each person was very patient and very professional. Cannot recommend this place enough!

31.description: They are so nice here. Really friendly and helpful, and as far as framing goes, not too pricey. They're also great at suggesting ways to bring the price down for a piece, (different frame, matting, etc). Definitely go here, it's a great small business.

34.description: This is the best place for framing in Chicago.  I stumbled upon their original location because the displays in the window were always so interesting.  So glad that I decided to go in.  I've being going to them for framing ever since and am enchanted by everything they've framed for me.  Owners are so dedicated to producing exceptional work.  I appreciate the care they've always taken with my pieces.  They have creative ideas to complete any piece of art and are extremely personable and professional.  Adorable pooches in the shop seal the deal.  Going in April 7s is always a great experience.  Selection of frames and mattes is extensive. If you care about what hangs on your walls, make sure you've had it framed by the pros at April 7s.

16.description: I'm probably jumping the gun on this review since I haven't gotten my frame yet. But I just love this place and these people. Sooooo nice and so polite! Not to mention, they have two dogs in the shop, which immediately won me over.I took my huge map in to get framed and the guy (I'm mad I can't think of his name) was super helpful and went to pick out a really sweet clean matte white frame to go with it. So minimalist. I love it.Be ready for an update when I get to pick it up!

13.description: When my daughter was born I bought an adorable picture frame that documented all her month bdays for the first year. I searched forever to find one that wasn't overly cheesy and found the perfect one on RedEnvelope. After 12 months I put Baby R's very last picture into my beloved frame...and was so excited to have a frame documenting her entire first year. A few days later it fell off the bookcase and shattered into a bunch of pieces. Ahhhh! My first thought was to reorder it from RedEnvelope and was devastated to see it had been discontinued. Apparently I was the only one buying it for myself and gifts.  I tried to find a similar frame, but couldn't find anything I liked nearly as much. And sooo I turned to Yelp to find a frame store to help me.I came across April 7s Custom Framing and took my shattered frame over to Marty. He was very sympathetic and promised to help me fix it.  I can't remember how much paid, but believed it was around $50...and said he would charge me the rest later (he thought it would be another $50-75, but said it would depend on if he had to build it again from scratch). And he said it would be ready in a few weeks. Three months later I was still waiting for the finished product and hadn't heard from April 7s because a voicemail after 3 weeks saying they'd need a bit more time.  I called Marty and asked what the deal was. He was extremely apologetic, promised to have it ready by that weekend and said he wouldn't charge me anymore than my initial payment.Marty was true to his word this time and did have it ready by the weekend. And when I picked it up I was excited to see that it looked even better than it initially looked. I'm pretty sure it would now withstand a fall off a bookcase, but then again I don't plan on trying it. And he also didn't charge me more than my initial payment even though he did end up having to completely rebuild it.Three months of waiting for something would usually result in a negative Yelp review, but Marty was such a pleasure to deal with that I actually still had a good experience. And I would actually even consider going back to him for other framing needs...he assured me that regular projects typically go much faster.

11.description: Great people who create a wonderful experience. If you like your art to be taken care of with the best service and solutions then this is the place to go.

39.description: My Dad sent me a print he got for participating in ChicagoFest VI at Soldier Field (1985 I think?).  It was wrapped in torn cellophane and glued to a Styrofoam "frame".  Quite frankly, I'm surprised it last 25 years!April 7s not only salvaged the print but they provided me with suggestions for matting and framing since I went in without a clue.  Looking at it now, no one could guess it has been sitting in a storage locker for the past quarter century.  While it's only a "poster", they treated it like a piece of art and understood the the sentimental value of what I brought them.  Great people, great service, and great product.

37.description: Love Marty! They do mounting as well. Super great job. Very professional and courteous. GO HERE!

0.description: The guys at April 7s are fantastic.  Truly, truly fantastic.  I bgouth five diplomas in to April 7s to be framed.  Two different guys helped me and my husband choose frames, mats, and glass for the diplomas.  They were well priced and they got the diplomas framed quickly.  They even found a program from my swearing in ceremony in the envelope with my law license and put a little pocket on the back of the frame to keep the program with it--free of charge.  It was so thoughtful and such a nice touch.  Fantastic local business that will really take care of you and anything you need framed.

38.description: Really these guys deserve 10 stars!  They are artists.  I took four pieces of art I had painted to their store a few weeks ago.  I wanted to get the pieces framed to gift them for Christmas.  Not only was Julie patient, she was conscious of the message of each piece and careful to think about the recipients character and style when matting/framing.  The art looks even more beautiful after April 7s work.  I will definitely return, and I recommend that you support this independent framing store.  By the way, artists get a discount.  Plus they're dog lovers!!!!

51.description: Simply the coolest ideas, the best execution and the nicest people in one store. Period. If you need some thing framed w/ amazing results for your hip pad....this is the place. Look no more.

27.description: Love. This. Place.Super helpful people, lovely recycled frames, and just really a pleasure to deal with.  I cannot say enough good things about them.

32.description: They have become our "go to" framers in Chicago. They always seem to be able to pick the right frame for the job. They really care about their work and community.

54.description: I don't bandy about this many stars lightly, but the folks at April 7s are simply the best at what they do. The first thing I ever asked them to frame was a 2ft by 10ft original work of art on a roll of butcher paper. It was, and remains, my most prized piece. I waltzed in, showed it to Martin. He unrolled it and laid it out with the care of a museum curator and we spent the next hour and a half talking through a good technique for framing this monster. It took a while to get this job done because of all the custom work required, but Martin made good and delivered beautiful work. I've gone back several times since. Martin approaches his work as the art form it is. Combine the quality work with their great customer service, charitable contributions and the perpetual art gallery that is their workspace, and you have the total package. In sum, April 7s is not the cheapest option for framing (you can pick up DIY frames from Target). April 7s is not the fastest option for framing (you can't rush this level of care and craftsmanship). April 7s is the best option for framing.

48.description: Based on previous stellar reviews, I had April 7s frame a 20x30" photograph of mine for a gallery show. I am very glad I did! Relaxed environment (two in-shop doggies!). Great selection. The owners & staff are engaging and happy to gently guide you toward the right choice for the work you bring in. Martin, who helped me initially, was very patient, as he watched me choose between two similar frames for quite a while. They also offered to stay after closing for me to come in.  I will be coming back to April7s for my future framing needs!

44.description: Great place.  I entrusted them with a print containing unusually dark and delicate black ink (that the artist warned could scratch EASILY).  They guided me through frame and mat choices and then went to work.  I couldn't be happier with the final results and am grateful that the piece is now properly protected and beautiful to view behind a pane of museum glass (more pricey but it reduces reflection which was key for this piece).  Their work alone is enough to get excited about but they are also real cool people.  I would recommend them to anyone.

24.description: We worked with Martin and got amazing service. He picked out several frames for us after hearing what we were looking for. He also gave us a variety of options with those frames to find the best price for us.This is the first frame store I've been to, but after visiting, we will not go anywhere else. It's great to be able to support local businesses and also get great customer service.

7.description: Thanks to all the great reviews I stopped at Aprils after breaking a painting on the way home from an art show.  Amazing customer service.  Fixed the painting in an hour!  I'll be back - a customer for life. Friendly service and great pricing. You won't be disappointed.

49.description: I picked these guys for custom framing because their reviews on here were AMAZING! They lived up to their reputation, and then some! I had a somewhat complicated triptych I wanted done, but with slightly different dimensions. I also came in with vague ideas of the types of frames I would like. The staff there looked at my art and each gave their opinions about what frames would look best and they were SOOO nice. My order was done exactly when they promised and it looked ten times better than I pictured. I will ALWAYS choose them in a heartbeat! Highest rating possible and well worth the cost!!!

40.description: I'm probably jumping the gun on this review since I haven't gotten my frame yet. But I just love this place and these people. Sooooo nice and so polite! Not to mention, they have two dogs in the shop, which immediately won me over.I took my huge map in to get framed and the guy (I'm mad I can't think of his name) was super helpful and went to pick out a really sweet clean matte white frame to go with it. So minimalist. I love it.Be ready for an update when I get to pick it up!

53.description: What a wonderful framing store.  I popped in today, a week before Christmas, with a print I wanted to get framed for my boyfriend.  I was greeted by two charming and friendly dogs, and a very nice young man with great smiling eyes.  He helped me pick out a perfect frame for the 14" by 24" art print I wanted framed, and worked with me to pick out the most economical but still very nice frame and glass for the print. The entire time he never pressured me to pick something more expensive, and he bent over backwards to help me choose the right frame to get completed within 24 hours. I paid on the spot and went home, thinking I'd just go back tomorrow to pick it up.I got a call 3 hours later that my framing was done!  The week before Christmas and April 7's was able to custom frame my print within HOURS?!  Outstanding.  Its gorgeous - sturdy, handsome, with a nice quality back papering and a copper hanging wire. I am so happy with how it came out, it was a shame to cover it up with wrapping paper - I want to hang it on the wall right now.I cannot thank April 7's enough and I will be back so soon with more things I need framed.  Support this local small business!

30.description: I have had several pieces framed here for myself and clients. I also recently purchased framed art they had hanging on their walls.This is the most amazing place to have framing done, pet a puppy and/or buy art work. I made a mistake with framing once and they were amazing about fixing it. Martin is amazing and helpful. I have been to framing shops from Michaels to gallery framing and April 7s is the best service and the best price.

46.description: I knew of April 7s because they were the home of my bird wall hangings that my husband bought me for Christmas the year before. We made mental note of their framing capabilities for future framing needs.For my birthday this year, I got my very first real pieces of artwork. Of course, I wasn't going to trust these pieces with any Average Joe Framer. No way. April 7s it was. The owners and their employees are friendly, kind, and full of good tips. They were helpful in figuring out colors of frames and what would best accentuate the artwork contained therein. The finished project was beautiful. It was exactly what I had ordered and made my beautiful screen prints even more lovely.Pricing is typical of what you pay for quality framing. You might not have the coupons from the big chain stores, but you will get customized frames at a competitive rate.We have since been back for a matting here and a frame there. It is really nice to patronize a local shop that gives you attentive customer service and has excellent advice. Gotta love the pups in the shop as well.April 7s is now my go-to for framers. (I feel like such an adult in that I need a go-to framer).

1.description: Hard to remember name.  But really nice work.  And I guess since it's the work and service that you pay for, I'll try to do better to remember the name.  But I can't make any promises!I had 4 pieces that needed to be matted and framed and were going to be hung in my office.  The tricky part?  They were all different sized vintage posters with different colors and highlights and yet needed to all look like they were a part of a set.Well these guys were great!  They started by pulling frames and mats off the walls and just about the time we think we've landed on something, my friend shows up and starts pulling even more options off the walls.  Good thing there wasn't anyone else in the shop or customers would have been shopping on my table!  Ha!After looking at many combinations, I picked what I thought worked the best and left the shop knowing I was going to love the work!  And when it was delivered a few weeks later, it was even better than I could have anticipated.The prices are in keeping with what you might expect to pay at any higher end frame shop.  Parking is a bit of a challenge here so know before you go if you are picking up a piece, they have a back entrance which makes it easy for them to put things in your car.  Otherwise you might get lucky and grab some street parking out front.Also know that the front door may be locked during open hours.  Seems like some people who really aren't interested in framing wander in from time to time so they lock the door, so be sure to ring the bell or knock and they will let you in very quickly.April 7's really did a nice job on my prints.  But then with all the great reviews here on Yelp. I expected nothing else.  Now, if only I could remember the name!

55.description: My husband and I just took our favorite wedding photos to April 7s and were very happy with our experience. The owners are very friendly and helpful and are great at listening to what you want and helping you get exactly that or better- they suggested some things we would not have thought of for the framing style and arrangement and we loved their ideas. We are very confident that when the framed pictures are ready to go and on our wall, we will be very happy we ended up using April 7s.

9.description: This is the second time I have been here. This time, worked with Martin's wife, her name escapes me. Brought in 4 pieces. Ended up doing 3 pieces due to budget constraints.  Was looking for something imaginative to make the pieces stand out for the new office I was decorating. Was shown several options that would compliment the frame and give me the look I was looking for. Prices are pretty much on par with other frame shops. Michaels charges just about the same if you use their 'custom frames' or custom framing services. Difference, in my opinion, is the artistic talent they share with you to help you design the frame and come up with ideas. If you have pictures that just need a standard frame, you would probably save money going elsewhere like target. Great place to go if you are looking for quality framing work done, to be creative with your frame, and/or want the frame to really showcase the art.

26.description: Wonderful place, they will spend plenty of time with you selecting the perfect frame - a task that usually takes me forever. And they have a great selection. The only reason I witheld one star is that sometimes the turnaround isn't as instantaneous as I'd like. But you can't expect next day frame service from a place that is rightfully busy!

25.description: Great service and great selection of unique frames at a variety of price points.  Really helpful consultation to get my picture framed up just right. The shop itself is welcoming and eclectic with a bunch of neat artwork displayed all over the walls.

12.description: What do you mean it normally takes more than 24 hours to custom frame a picture?I'm sorry I forgot the guys name, but he could not have been more helpful. Knowing he had to turn it around quickly using stuff they have in the shop already, he spent a full hour with me digging up different options for mattes and frames. He gave great suggestions and assisted while I putzed around taking my time deciding which frame to use.  Could not have been a better customer service experience.I was tempted to give one less star just because the price seemed high, but you know what, I have no idea what custom framing costs. I think it costs more than I want it to cost. Maybe if I had framing done frequently, I might be wise to shop around for a good deal.  But since I have something framed about once every ten years or so, this was a pretty wise choice.

59.description: Had a couple of prints framed here and they did an amazing job.  they can make a 50 dollar print look like it's worth 5000 dollars.  The people that work here are super friendly and helpful with all your framing needs.

21.description: I've had a few pieces framed here and each time I'm impressed with how helpful and creative they are.The last time I brought in a very large piece to be framed. They were able to help me select the perfect frame and delivered and installed the picture when it was done, which was fantastic since there was no way I would have been able to fit it in my car. They even gave my chubby, over-friendly cat lots of love and attention when they were at my place hanging the picture on the brick wall. Great people and great work; I'm a loyal April 7's customer.

17.description: You get what you pay for. And here you pay for high-quality custom framing and get pleasantly surprised by the results. These guys were incredibly friendly and knowledgeable about how best to preserve and present my items. Their excellent service was matched by the quality of the work they completed in a timely fashion. I would recommend April 7s to anyone with a valuable item they want beautifully displayed who is okay with paying for high-quality work from a local small business. And they have a friendly dog.

10.description: Very professional, courteous and knowledgeable. I bought three of their Yelp vouchers and have been very happy with all six items I've framed. Highly recommend!

5.description: These guys have helped my photo business my getting my clients the framing they needed in a timely manner.

3.description: Just the best, really. Very highly recommended!

35.description: First things first, the duo who run this shop have a great eye for what frame would work with your piece o' art.  I had a vintage 1960s Fernet Branca poster and they picked a very nice looking white gloss frame that looked great against the predominantly orange hues of the poster.Second, framing ain't cheap.  For real, every time I frame something I cry a little inside because of how much it costs.  And April 7s is no exception, but let me just say that the prices are fair and middle of the pack.  Data: my poster was 35 x 50.5, so pretty darn big, and I used UV plexi, and I needed to have the poster backed with mumbo jumbo for preservation purposes.  $279 for the frame, $162 for plexi, and $55 for preservation mumbo jumbo.  With tax, this was just short of $550.  Like I said, I almost cried.  But you gotta do what you gotta do (what's the alternative, thumb tacks?).Third, service was great here.  April 7s had stated that the job would take two weeks, but it actually took four weeks, which was not a big deal to me, but they knocked off $100 from the price, which was awesome.  Also, they delivered to my house at an odd time for no charge.In short: framing costs money, but you might as well have it look good and come from cool people.

19.description: Just as the other reviewers have said: Martin is incredibly knowledgeable and helpful in providing options. Work quality was fantastic! (you get what you pay for!)

28.description: I love April 7s. I've had Martin frame three different pieces for me. He is so lovely to work with and so calm and just NICE. He will really consult with you about what might be best for your piece and it's always fun to see the other works that he has up on the wall. I really love these guys and can't recommend them enough. Super nice people, huge selection of frames and mats, knowledgeable staff, and quality work. It doesn't get much better!!!

45.description: April 7s is nothing short of AMAZING!!!!  I had a wonderful experience with them, and I would recommend them and use them again for all of my framing needs.  They really take as much time as you need to assist you in selecting the perfect frame.  Their prices are reasonable for the very high quality of their work.  I had three pieces framed shortly before I was moving out of Chicago.  They made sure to have the pieces done on time and even offered to deliver to my home since I was so busy preparing for the move.  Look no further - you will not be disappointed!

33.description: When my daughter was born I bought an adorable picture frame that documented all her month bdays for the first year. I searched forever to find one that wasn't overly cheesy and found the perfect one on RedEnvelope.
